reviewText: The basic premise of Legend of Grimrock is that it is a modern take on the classic grid-based,dungeon-crawling,RPG games of old, like Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder etc. You start out with a party of 4 adventurers (arranged in a 2x2 formation)... in this case convicted as criminals and thrown into a secure prison.. and must explore the prison/dungeon to learn its secrets and find a way out. Movement is directional, plus rotate left and right, around a series of 2 dimensional grid based levels. There are various monsters to fight and puzzles to solve in order to progress through the game. Fighting is done by means of clicking on the items equipped in your characters' hands, often whilst performing a Square dance" with the monsters to avoid letting them hit your party\n\nThe graphics have been updated
hoursPlayed: but repeating textures are still used widely
voteText: and the gameplay itself is very reminiscent of the early games. Objects are interacted with by click on the screen e.g. to press a button or open a door and items can be picked up and carried/used by your party of adventurers. The adventurers attack by left-clicking the items that are placed in their hands
helpfulPercent: and spells can be cast by choosing the right combination of runes for a spell the adventurer has learnt.\n\nThere are 4 races:- Humans; Minotaurs; Lizardmen; and Insectoids

reviewText:
An indie game that made an impact so hard that Ubisoft resurrected Might & Magic title (in the M&M X Legacy), after so many years of oblivion.
An old-school dungeon crawler which is a perfect picture of how the progress goes.
See, when somebody invents a new mechanic or some better technology, it doesn't mean we should wipe all that was made before. And sometimes older tricks are better than newer ones. Take the chess game as precedent. Or even better example: Horses. We still ride them, but now we don't need to drive them to death to catch up with something. Riding horses today can be educational, emotional, engaging boost of experience. It can even heal some poor hearts, you know.

The Elder Scrolls Arena was much like the Grimrock by the mechanics, but eventually we've got Skyrim, which gives a completely another experience than that brilliant of game design we're talking there. The Skyrim can get you on the top of the world... but in the Legend of Grimrock you'll get much more emotions per time spended. And more challenges, both of fighting and exploring nature.

Legend of Grimrock has almost no plot. Yes, somewhere in the background, we have a story of four convicts who were thrown into perdition to inhabited by monsters and traps bristling labyrinth of dungeons. Throughout accompany us also to be found in various places notes made ​​by a man named Tooruma, who wandered through the corridors and halls before us. At each level during sleep appear visions" with a few sentences. And that's basically all the elements of the story.

reviewText:
I had played this game for a bit in the past, less then a few minutes because I could never figure out how combat worked and would always get killed off from the snail. Then the other night I started it up again and tried playing once more not expecting to get far or play to long. However I found myself playing for over an hour and was able to figure out what I couldn't before, so here is my review on a very awesome game.

The Legend of Grimrock, a game I bought on Steam a couple years ago during the 2012 summer sale event made by Almost Human Games[www.grimrock.net].

The game is an old school RPG that is not turn based but live action. In other words you are able to move, cast spells, select items from your inventory and rest without waiting for creatures to take their turn. As your trying to get your spell cast or looking for a throwing item in your inventory the creature will be attacking you and won't sit there and wait till your done.

I really found this game to have that pen and paper D&D feel to it and I like the idea of selecting the option to not have the game do the mapping as I explore and then I can map it out with graph paper and a pencil (I didn't do this of course).

The character creation screen is very simple with 4 races and 3 classes to choose from.  The inventory and character screen isn't complex or confusing but very intuitive and easy to figure out and understand.

The spell's though are based on symbols and you have to select the right symbols or combination of to cast the spell. I found that you couldn't get the spell unless you found the scroll for the right spell but this could have been because I wasn't selecting the right symbol until I found the scroll.

When venturing through the dungeon your characters will get hungry and there will be a symbol of food in there avatar picture indicating they need to eat. When you kill of creatures they will sometimes leave a meat chunk behind and you will want to get these to eat along with any food things you find along the way.

During combat along the way some of your party member may die, take heart because they are not gone for good. You will be able to access their inventory while dead to. There will be these big blue floating crystals that when touched will restore your party to full health and energy and raid the dead. Remember where these ones are. Once they are used you will have to wait for a bit till it can be clicked on again.

Now as for combat, where I originally had most of my troubles. To attack all you need simply do is right click on your hand under your avatar (wither their is a weapon in it or not). If your a spell caster you will want to keep at least one hand empty for right clicking to bring up the symbol window for spell casting.

When you left click on a throwing weapon it will be attached to your mouse cursor and if you click with it again with your mouse pointer above the midline of the screen (the top half of the window) then it will be thrown. If you click below the midline (bottom half of the screen) then it get dropped on the floor.

This is a keyboard and mouse type game and no controller support.

Now that I have been able to find out something about the game and how combat works, along with the abilities to make your own dungeon's and storyline and the Steam Workshop to try some community based dungeons, The Legend of Grimrock is one game to have in your collection. Its worth a play!

I give this game:
ːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starː

reviewText:
I have never played a game like this before and as my very first try at a first person dungeon crawler, I have to say this was a great experience. It might be newer and easier compared to the old ones, but this was a very good take on an old genre that is pretty much dead these days. The RPG elements are fairly light, but they definitely work and it was enjoyable to kill things and level up while finding new and better gear. The puzzles were great and generally enjoyable...mostly logic puzzles with some small hints. The vast majority of them made sense instead them being seemingly random like puzzles in some games.

The entire environment is all tile-based, but looked very good. A few levels would look like mossy rocks and then a few floors down they would nice, clean stonewalls, while deeper down it would be even more different. The lighting is awesome as well. It definitely set the mood for this game. The music was decent, but nothing to write home about - mostly ambient stuff. The story wasn't bad, but it wasn't super in-depth either. It was decent enough to make you want to continue your journey though.

I would have never played this game had it not been for a certain youtuber that showed me how awesome this game was. They ended up not finishing the game, but I'm very glad I finally finished it myself and I hope they do at some point as well. You know who you are!

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock is a modern looking version of the old dungeon crawling genre.
What is dungeon crawling? You might ask, well a dungeon crawler is a first person game where you play as an adventurer, or usually a party of adventurers that delve into dungeons, level up and complete quests, what makes dungeon crawlers so much different from modern RPG's  is that dungeon crawlers often use complex puzzles in their level design, making it more of a puzzle game than a grindfest.

The game starts you off with a standard party of four characters that work well together, but you can create your own party of course!
The characters you play are outcast by society and have to fight for their lives to have their crimes abolished on the mountain of Grimrock.

The game looks simply gorgeous for a game in it's genre, even on my terrible terrible laptop it runs very smooth at the maximum graphical settings.
The combat system is a bit like the old Final Fantasy/Chrono Trigger combat system mixed in with the Dungeon Master/Shin Megami Tensei combat, you can move about freely in a grid of squares, while your attacks aren't turnbased, they just have cooldowns.

The challenge this game holds is above average, don't expect to blaze through it on your first playthrough, nonetheless it's a great game overall!
The puzzles don't let you get stuck for a long time, they're quite clear about what needs to be done, which is a good thing in my opinion.

I could whole-heartedly recommend you this title if you want to play a casual game with a decent bit of challenge, especially when it's on sale, then it's definately worth the money.
If you're on the fence about this game, I'd say go and buy it, if you weren't interested before, this probably isn't your type of game, and I'd recommend you watching a let's play.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock is an old-school dungeon crawling game which is inspired by games like Dungeon Master oder Eye of the Beholder.

The game tells a story of four criminals whose crimes are forgotten by getting tossed into the maw of mount Grimrock. A massive mountain which holds a huge dungeon of untold horrors. No one has ever managed to escape this atrocity. No one but, well you might guessed it, you !

You are in control of the four criminals. You can either chose a preset of four ready-to-go characters or create your own party. Once you are in the Dungeon your job is to find a way out. You can move your party from tile to tile and can only perform 90° turns to the left or right. This sounds quite simple and to many quite boring, but Legend of Grimrock does a fantastic job of keeping things fresh and interesting.

As you progress through the dungeon you have to solve puzzles which become increasingly harder and sometimes force you to think in unconventional ways. But they are never unfair and can be solved with a decent amount of thinking and experimenting. The puzzles are the highlights of the game which are quite rewarding in most cases and keep you motivated as you progress deeper into the dungeon.

The combat system is rather simple but still challenging. As already mentioned you control four characters which are always standing on the same tile. On the bottom right of the screen you got the avatars of you characters which are also used to control you characters. If you left-click on a equipped melee weapon you will perform an attack with this weapon. The twist about this system is that the upper row of your characters represent the front row on the tile you are standing. Characters in the back row cant hit targets with melee weapons / attacks (with a few exceptions). So you are forced to build a solid mix of beefy warriors / melee characters that stand in front and weaker but also very useful range characters that stand in the back and cast spells or use throwing weapons or other types of ranged attacks.

If you have a mage in your party things really become interesting. The spell-system requires you to combine several runes in order to sucessfully cast a spell. And you have to do this during the fight in real time. So things can get a bit stressful if you fight off several enemies because you still want to use your other characters. There are no shortcuts you could use. You have to memorize the runes and the combinations to put your mage to use. To some of you this might sound disappealing but if you get the hang of it, it feels really great.

Technically the developers have done a great job. Some light effects in Legend of Grimrock are really great to look at, the textures are very sharp, the animations of enemies are great and fluid.

One of the downsides of this game is that it may lack a bit of variation. There are only 3 different looks in the dungeon. Some of you might think that this it no problem because a dungeon is a dungeon but even in that particular scenario you could do more than three different types of wall textures.

All in All Legend of Grimrock is a great expierence if you like solving challenging but rewarding puzzles and if you love exploration because you get to explore a lot. There are a lot of secrets to uncover in this vast dungeon.

reviewText:
This game just rocks. I never played this kind of game before, so I can't say it's an old-school experience for me, but I can see what they mean.

There are no auto generated dungeons
The loot is carefully placed and hand selected
The fights involve you being skilled with you directional movement
There are no shops or farms or anything, when you can't carry stuff anymore you have to discard something, so keep you inventory organized. Every item counts
There are secrets all over the place and it is actually rewarding to find them
Ammo is scare, I found a total of 22 arrows and bolts in my play through, if you waste them, your problem (you can collect them from dead enemies)
There is no auto-aim or anything like that - you need to run, choose your direction, click on specific runes and hit your weapons all that the same time! oh and noticed that hole in the floor, whaaaaaaaaa
Everything is wrapped in really awesome graphic packageSo if you like a game that challenges you, that makes you think and explore. Get this one now!

reviewText: Playing this with the sequel in mind, it's a much simpler, more confined experience, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. Where the sequel is much more open and encourages exploration, this one's more about overcoming the dungeon before you, going deeper and deeper, floor by floor, as challenges and rewards alike escalate. You won't get lost, but you'll find plenty of secrets if you poke around a little. It's shorter, but there's much less time spent wandering.\n\nPlayed without the sequel in mind, this is God's gift to dungeon-crawl fans, taking all the old-school things you enjoyed and decorating them in modern graphics and sound. It's not as hard, even on hard, as those older games, but it captures the spirit of them perfectly with solid mechanics and atmosphere. It's a fantastic adventure, even if the final act is a bit of a letdown, and well worth playing even if you've already played the fancier second game.

reviewText:
A great start for this indie team and the best of luck with Grimrock 2.  The game itself harkens back to the old dungeon crawlers,  for me the memory of the dungeon aspect in Dungeons & Dragons: Warriors of the eternal sun,  where you get or create a set group of characters and trudge about solving puzzles, unearthing secrets and battling the minions in the pit that were thrown into.

A beautiful game a little finicky on the magic caster but a great look back at the old square based movement era.

Highly recommend.

reviewText:
If you're below a certain age (around 25-30) you may be wondering why this game is in a tile format; why you can't just walk around freely in any direction like in Skyrim, for example. It's because this game is a modern take on old dungeon crawler games from the 80's and early 90's. They were made like this because of technological limitations but in my opinion they work just as well today as they did then and Legend of Grimrock captures the feel of that perfectly. You are 4 prisoners who have been accused of unknown crimes and tossed in to the dungeons of a mountain. As you were thrown in your crimes were absolved and if you can make it through the maze of tunnels, monsters and puzzles and come out the other side in one piece your crimes will be forgotten.

You can choose from 4 races (human, minotaur, lizard or insectoid) and each has certain differences that make them unique. Minotaur are very aggressive and strong and so make great fighters, for example. There are also 3 classes to choose from: warrior, rogue and mage. As you level up you can further customize your characters by spending skill points, so as a mage you can choose to focus on fire magic and become very proficient in that, or you can spread your points out evenly and be good at all schools of magic. Similarly with a rogue you can choose between missile weapons, throwing weapons or fast melee weapons/backstabs with daggers and the like.

The puzzles and monsters start off easy but get harder as the game progresses - all the clues to solve them are there though in the form of cryptic messages written on walls and notes left by other prisoners who have tried to escape before you. Each level has secret rooms that can usually be found by pushing a button" - a loose rock hidden in a wall somewhere. They're not too difficult to find but you do have to keep your eyes open.

I love this game and it reminds me of the good old days of classic dungeon crawlers like Eye of the Beholder. If I was forced to say something negative about it (which I guess I am because this is a review) then it would be that some enemies are quite easy to defeat by hitting them and then sidestepping before they can hit you - though this is actually a valid tactic in games these. Even so
date: a mistake can get you killed
recommended: for example if you allow yourself to be cornered a troll - it'll wear your hit points down fast because they hit like a train. You need to give yourself room to manouver.\n\nI'd give it a 4/5. It's one of the best quality indie games you'll ever find

reviewText: Takes all the good elements from old-school dungeon crawlers like Dungeon Master and executes them perfectly. The UI and general handling of the game is that intuitively that you know everything you need to know after the first minutes into the game. And the developers didn't make any major changes to the retro mechanics, but they polished them. I love such details.\nOnly tiny thing I'd wish for is a hotkey to toggle secondary weapons, because in the heat of the battle it's rather annoying to switch to a distance weapon (currently they are basically spamming my inventory).\nIf you like this genre this game is a must.

reviewText:
Right off the bat im going to say that this game isn't for everyone.  You're definately going to have to be nostalgic about first person dungeon crawlers from the 90's to really enjoy this game.

That being said this game is fantastic.  The difficulty curve is great, the games starts out with easy battles and simple puzzles and builds in difficulty throughout the entire game to nerve wracking battles and extremely challenging puzzles.  The visuals are outstanding, but the same stone walled environments get really repetitive and boring after awhile.  The base game netted me around 20 hours of play, with steam workshop included though this game keeps you updated with plenty of fresh user created content.

If you love games like Dungeon Master and Might and Magic than definately pick this game up during the next steam sale.

reviewText: Unlike a lot of others, I wasn't around for the golden age of PC gaming. Back when you had to draw your own maps and read the manuals that came with the game. But when I bought this game a couple summers back, it made me wish I had.\nThis game has revived the dungeon crawling genre. It's fleshed out, interesting, and well done. Graphically pleasing and is one of the few games that has puzzles I enjoy. (They can certainly stump you) It's only flaws are the scenery can get a bit dull and the enemy AI is easily fooled (Only if you have four squares to dodge around. Otherwise, you're ♥♥♥♥ed, dude.) but it's certainly a good purchase if this is your type of game.

reviewText:
Wow.

This is a WOW game.

This game doesn't have cutting edge graphics, the audio is slightly better than average, and the genre is as old as, what, the 1980s?

This game isn't great because of some stupid parlor trick. It's good because it's a near-perfect implementation of a specific class of game; the old PC dungeon crawler.

If you love finding secret wall switches, solving puzzles and finding loot, and eating a giant roasted maggot-on-a-stick because you're desperate to eat, then this is the game for you.

If you want a fantasy FPS with lots of jumping and airducking, this isn't for you, GTFO.

Legend of Grimrock doesn't try and improve much on the old classic dungeon crawler game design, I think that works well for it, and I don't think they do anything really new or crazy that hasn't been done in dungeon crawlers before. They just put modern graphics and sound together into a game and implemented it well.

The game doesn't have any music beyond the title screen, but the ambient background through the game is pleasant and detailed. Turn the volume up, because sounds of the dungeon will alert you to nearby foul beasts and secrets.

The background story is compelling and interesting, but nothing too deep. Secrets are found in the dungeon, and a reason for being is evident, but they leave the details up to your imagination, which is probably for the best. You can't climb back up. Your only way out is down. The story is your journey along the way.

The last few levels are spooky and the game has a very fulfilling final battle.

Secrets are plentiful, so pay attention. There were a couple of puzzles which had me really baffled, including two that were required to proceed with the story. I don't recomend ruining the challenge for yourself by reading a walkthrough online, but if you get stuck in the story, it's there for you. The best thing to do is sit and think. With two specific exceptions that I can mention, most of the puzzles are evident if you just use your brain for more than thirty seconds.

I do have a complaint regarding the final puzzle in the game (Minor spoiler warning): There are four items which need to be placed around a single block in a room. Two of them are pretty easy to figure out, but the small gear in particular has a non-obvious arbitrary placement location which should be fixed. Even if you have the right item on the right wall, you have to click it on a very specific small area that doesn't offer any clue that it's the right part to go in the right place.

Also, the level 9 riddle room had me really stuck for awhile. I just didn't get the clues and had to randomly guess at it until I figured it out.

reviewText: A lot of people who were PC gamers in the late 80s and early 90s have fond memories of dungeon crawlers like Dungeon Master and Eye of the Beholder. This game perfectly reboots the rustic subgenre that many veteran gamers remember all on a modern engine with many of the familiar quirks. Throughout the entirety of the game, you’ll be descending downward into the unknown with a party of four to solve puzzles that become increasingly complex and fight a variety of enemies. Opening the iron doors on each level and finding secrets is also critical if you want to find good gear.\n\nIf you're looking for a dungeon crawler RPG that will send you down a nostalgia trip, then you’ve come to the right place. Even as someone who never grew up playing these types of games I can say that my experience with this game has been wonderful. I’d suggest this game to anyone who is looking for a fun dungeon crawling experience that won’t break the bank.

reviewText: This is definitely and old school style dungeon crawler RPG and I can say that because I was actually gaming back in the 80s. The visuals were nice as well as the sound and music, but the game could be brutally difficult at times. I usually pride myself on not using guides and walkthroughs to solve puzzles in games, but this game caused me to have to do that a few times. I felt like some of the puzzles required you to make such large leaps of deduction that I found myself at times just trying random things, or trying different patterns until I got lucky and opened the door or found the secret. Also, the combat system could be a little off-putting and didn't fit with the theme of the game. Would four party members really do square dancing in a dungeon with an ogre? I beat the game and the story was OK, but even though I try to be a completist, I still left many secrets, treasure, and weapons unfound as I traversed all the levels of the game. Overall, I liked it but I will probably never play it again. It just got to grindy towards the end and I just wanted it to be over.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TRh5EtboE2A&feature=youtu.be

Legend of Grimrock: a classic dungeon crawling role-playing game. Legend of Grimrock gets it right by keeping the premise simple and making the game easy and interactive while making sure to put the challenge in the combat and the puzzle solving.

You were four prisoners who were shoved into the depths of Mount Grimrock to atone for your crimes, you are free the moment you fall, however you have to escape Grimrock if you want to enjoy your freedom, and that’s the story. There are tidbits of lore and story in scroll, text on walls and various objects you find throughout Grimrock, its simple and that’s honestly for the best.

The game plays up the survival part well with needing to keep your guys fed or risk of getting hungry, health and energy regenerate although slowly, you can rest but risk getting attacked while resting.

Graphics weren’t top notch for the time it came out, but they don’t feel dated or old, they’re more than adequate and the style of the dungeon and its inhabitants is very realistic in tone.  There is no music throughout most of the game; instead you get this creepy ambiance similar to Amnesia or Penumbra games. It isn’t meant to scare as much as it is to create a tone of dread from  hearing ‘things’ in the distance, again the game feels like it’s going more for a realistic immersion.

Combat is much more interesting and tactical, your team is in a 2x2 formation, two in front and back, the two in front are taking the brunt of the damage while the two in back are support, you can switch these positions easily and you often will in order to save companions from death or to rotate dealing damage, spells are cast by selecting the correct rune sequence, you can do this as long as your skill level lets you and you know the combination, you can find scrolls that tell you correct rune combinations, but these aren’t required, you can find them through experimentation, or if you don’t care about finding it out, the internet.

You can also craft in this game various potions from the reagents you find in Grimrock, potions can be simple healing or energizing potions to better damage or even invisibility, again you can find the correct combination through experimentation or scroll and recipes.

Finally the puzzles in the game are much more challenging, there are a few simple and easy ones to begin with, but, even in the first room you start in there are various secret switch to hidden treasures, and as you progress the game starts putting more challenging riddles up for you to solve, some necessary to progress others to great treasures to help you survive. Overall, I felt the puzzle solving in this game was a good balance between challenging while also not needing to be overly difficult.

Legend of Grimrock is a great throwback to dungeon crawling RPGs, it shows that this type of game can easily be done and be fun if done well, it’s simple and easy to get into and actually gave me quite a challenge and I was really impressed once I finished the game, it took me about 20 hours to beat the game, and for $14.99 USD that is not bad at all. I highly recommend this game if you’re looking for good ole fashioned role-playing games, or just something different from the standard fair now-a-days, if you need that more action oriented role-playing game, Grimrock may not be for you, although I still feel it’s just as fun, if not more.

TL/DL; Legend of Grimrock is a classic dungeon crawling RPG with up to 20 hours of gameplay at only $14.99 USD, it’s a steal and well worth the price, its challenging, creepy, and interesting, it’s simple in its gameplay and story making it easy to jump in, it’s worth checking it out of you enjoy RPGs in general, if you need more action oriented RPGs, it may not be for you, but, I encourage you to check it out, you won’t regret it.

-Double Thumbs Up from Royial

Video Reviews: https://www.youtube.com/RoyialNetwork

reviewText:
LoG is based off the old school RPG’s from early PC days and I think there may have even been a few on consoles. I never played much in this FPS style when I was younger but that doesn’t take away how much fun this game was to play.

You have a team of 4 characters and move through a grid based dungeon you were locked up in. You can create your characters with a variety of classes, powers, and skills to whatever playstyle fits you best. There are many floors to travel through and many secrets to find on the way. There are plenty of great challenging puzzles and enemies to keep you occupied for a good time.

There is also plenty of replay value with different difficulties and even an old-school mode where you lose the AutoMap and you can pull out some grid paper and make your own. Then there is also the added Steam Workshop where you can install mods to give you more challenges and fun to last you a long time.

The game is fantastic looking with some cool character design and great sound to go along with it. Going through the tunnels when your torch is flickering out and you can hear the skittering of an enemy somewhere nearby made for some cool moments in the game.

I played through on easy mode as I’m new to this style of RPG and figured I could get the hang of it better. It was still a decent challenge and enjoyable for me. I would highly recommend Legend of Grimrock if you like the old-school RPGs or even just want to play a well-made fantastic game. This is Almost Human’s first game and you can tell they put a lot of love into it and it was only a 4 man team too. Don’t pass this game up.

reviewText:
Finally a dungeon crawler for modern age!
This is a lovely homage to the old school grid based dungeon crawler genre, easy enough to learn so the younger generation of gamers can enjoy it, but truly challenging enough what older gamers would expect.
Well balanced, fun, proper achievements and hours of gameplay with an affordable price tag.
Highly recommended for anyone who love single player adventure and rpg-games in fantasy style.

Be aware though that if you never had played any grid based dungeon crawler games before, the controls will probably feel a little awkward for the first minutes, but just learn how to move properly and soon you will be dancing around the enemies :)

reviewText:
It's not a terrible game, but it falls short of its predecessors. The Dungeon Master and Eye of the Beholder series were much better games than this one. Let me list the good and bad  points:
-- Good --
- The graphics are sharp. Thumbs up in this department.
- The monsters actually behave differently depending on their type, giving you the idea that they aren't just sacks of hitpoints charging at you.
- A lot of secrets to uncover.
- Most levels have a healing crystal that will instantly heal your party and resurrect fallen members.

-- Bad --
- The magic system is terrible. Both DM and EOB had a rich magic system with a lot of useful spells, both combat and utility. This game has essentially 6 or 7 spells. (There are actually more than this, but in essence a fire arrow spell is the exact same as a lighting/poison/frost arrow, so I am calling it one spell.) Of these, the only real utility spell is a light spell. No healing spells, no create food spells, no detect secrets spells - nothing. This was my #1 biggest complaint with this game.
- The puzzles are mostly of the 'hit a switch and race to this location to hit another one' variety. I want puzzles that test my cunning, not my reflexes.
- Most of the monsters in the game are about impossible to stand toe-to-toe with. The game relies heavily on the 'attack and sidestep' school of combat. It's wasn't fun in EOB, and it isn't fun here. I understand it for a boss fight, but here it is necessary with most monsters, at least until you are way over their level.
- THERE ARE NO HOTKEYS! You have to use your mouse to manually click each party member's weapon in order to attack. Come on guys - even Might and Magic had combat hotkeys! This is annoying with melee attacks, but downright aggravating when it comes to magic. To cast a spell, you have to right-click your wand, select the runes (up to 3), and then click again. Want to cast that spell again? Ok, 5 more clicks coming right up. All this while trying to sidestep and manage 3 other party members' melee attacks.

My recommendation is go back and play DM or EOB. They are much better (although uglier) games.

reviewText: What shall i say? It feels (and plays) like the good old times"-dungeon crawlers
date:
yet looks modern with more than decent graphics and models. It even looks pretty great with 3D Glasses (Helix).

Do i recommend it? YES! But only if you liked them old crawler or these things sound interesting to you if you don't know them at all:

- building a party you'll never really see except their portraits (get the fat pack from nexusmods!)
- wander around a dungeon room by room and not step by step (no free movement)
- fighting monsters with a simple click or casting spells by recalling the patterns (from easy to less easy)
- rest to heal/refresh mana
- use the mouse to find possible switches or something on wall/grounds (point-and-click-adventure-like)
- solving minor puzzles of switches/traps/whatnot
- die and reload :-)

I really liked it (so much that i just bought it on steam just to support the developers. Hence my few playtime). And I'm no hardcore old-schooler

reviewText: Featuring an old school experience of  paper/pencil rogue-like games that the 80's and 90's were famous for, Legend of Grimrock successfully updates the genre while maintaining emphasis on difficulty, customizable parties, and lore. Rich in story, secrets and diverse gameplay, Legend of Grimrock serves up a great platform for players looking for challenging yet ultimately rewarding gameplay.

reviewText:
Pure dungeon crawling goodness.
This is not dragon age. It is repetitve, a bit on purpose since it's a dungeon crawling game.

You begin your quest half-naked and you try to get out of this maze.
Oh, and your torch burned out. Woops.
It's dark and you hear something coming your way.

So it's hack n slash everything, try to resolve some puzzles.
Loot what you can.
So far I did not see real role playing.

I say if you are into ''classic'' dungeon crawling this is a must-play.

reviewText: If you like games such as Kings Field, Stonekeep, etc. This game is for you. I was a little confused with the controls at first, but they are easy to get the hang of. I suggest making your own characters as that is fun in itself. The dungeon has many secrets hiding surprizes, and hidden rooms galore. You will have to look very carefully, and some puzzles may stump you.\n\nCombat involves strafeing, plus timing your attacks so you take the least amount of damage. There are blue crystals hidden on each floor that save your game, and heal diseased characters if you happen to get caught by a trap like i did my first time playing. In short, i do recommend this title.

reviewText:
Every now and then there comes a game that tries to revisit genres that have fallen by the wayside as the video game industry continues to change and grow. Dungeon crawler games, for the most part, happen to be one of those genres. So when I first saw images for Legend of Grimrock I couldn’t help but be excited.

When I was a kid I spent a lot of time playing the old dungeon crawler games. I still vividly remember such titles as Dungeon Master and Dungeon Master II: The Legend of Skullkeep. Given how much time I spent playing those games, and loving every minute of it, I was hoping that this new game would live up to the games in whose footsteps it was following.

I’ll tell you right now, I have not been disappointed.

Legend of Grimrock is everything it is supposed to be. It is an old-style dungeon crawler modernized for today’s gaming world. While such a game can be limited in terms of graphics and art style, Almost Human, the indie developer behind the title, has executed it perfectly. The game looks great and the various creatures’ appearances are fantastic given the limits of the genre.

Read the rest of my review at Press2Reset: http://press2reset.com/reviews/review-legend-of-grimrock/

reviewText:
This is a great tribute to the first person RPG's of yesteryear, such as Dungeon Master and the Eye of the Beholder series.

Combat is difficult, and requires careful maneuvering as well as the right builds for your characters.  Some of the puzzles are fiendishly difficult, but all of them are fair, and I only had to go searching for solutions a couple of times on my first play through.

Graphically, the game does what it sets out to do very well, though the tile sets and enemy types are all limited.  Even so, the look of the game, combined with what turns out to be a surprisingly good sound track add to the intense atmosphere of the whole experience.

The whole thing gives off an almost 'survival horror meets fantasy rpg' hybrid, and one that I greatly enjoyed.  I recommend it highly.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Old school RPG ala Dungeon Masters and eyes of beholders. Wow, didn't expect to see a game like this in 2013.  Hardcore like the old days.  Younger players might be disappointed in the gameplay mechanics so know what you are buying.  Great game, great puzzles, and great nostalgia.

*Update* completed the game.  Seriously hardcore stuff and very unforgiving.  Due to a lack of time and sometimes general frustration with certain puzzles, I supplemented with a walk through.  Without the walkthrough, this game would had taken me months like I did with dungeon master or quit entirely.

Overall, very enjoyable.  Well done.

reviewText:
This game is great! It is a spiritual sequel to the old game Dungeon Master from the 80s, but with modern graphics and updates like better AI and an automap. If you like dungeon crawls, get it. You wont be disappointed.

Its a dungeon crawl like Eye of the Beholder. Graphics are very nice with the traditional square tunnels and chains hanging on the walls, moss ect. Theres alos the occasioanl cool statue or art on the walls as well. Step, turn, strafe and so forth. The puzzles ramp up in difficulty nicely. They are the typical find keys, secret buttons, pull levers in order, run quickly, and so forth. But defintely not stale. Theres also some interesting and unique ones too.  Combat is heavily reliant on the step dance just to survive, a feature I'm not too thrilled about. Unless youre a minmaxer, going toe to toe with an enemy of the appropriate level (on Normal) is not recommended.

Youre going to be freezing the enemy and/or dancing all over the place if you want to stay alive. The enemies hit hard. I would say that this is the games major flaw, as I'm way more of a fan of toe to toe melee than swinging and running all over the place till the enemy dies. Its too bad cuz the AI is nice for a square based dungeon crawler. The enemies will actually try and sneak up on you.

DMs levelling system was better too. In LoG, theres 4 races and 3 classes. Minotaur, human, lizardman, and insectoid, and mage, rogue and fighter. Once you pick, you're that class. Fighters cant learn magic, and mages cant fight (or seem to do much of anything). And you get XP, just like typical RPGs.

Contrast that with DMs practice a skill and level in that class" style and it just seems...lesser. Also
date: the game really lends itself to specialization. Pick 1 weapon
recommended: 1 magic school. Jack of all trading as far as class skills seems to really hurt in the late game.\n\nThe sounds and music are nice
hoursPlayed: typically dungeon-y without being too intrusive. There really isnt too much of a plot in the main game
voteText: but thats not why you're here. You're here for the awesome exploration
helpfulPercent: wondering whats around the corner and seeing if your condemned prisoners will ever win their freedom.\n\nAll in all a great game and definitely worth picking up for any dungeon/RPG fan. Theres a custom dungeon I have

commentsCount: you can chat with them. And you only design one char
column16: picking from the 4 races
column17: but also 4 classes
column18: each with 4 subclasses all slightly different."

reviewText: Former Dungeons & Dragons' player? Buy this bloody game then! It's amazing, thrown into a dungeon with nothing you've to work your way out of it facing enigmas, fights, levelling up your four characters (which you can build as you wish, from the class to the race before starting the adventure), casting spells, finding secrets. It's really awesome, sure it can't be as good as having someone continously shaping the story as you make decisions, but as videogame it's a very good game for any RPG-lover. If you need a rating: 8/10 you can even play custom dungeons made by others. Jeez what are you waiting for? Go and buy it!

reviewText: Warning: this game is challenging. If you're after another easy FPS this is definitely not the right game for you. You will need to think. You will need to dance with enemies to not die. You will probably die a lot. You will probably have a good time, too. It's also a good length (my playthrough took 16 hours, but it didn't feel long). Sure, there's only three different tilesets (old bricks, less old bricks, and metal bits), there are only two other characters in the game and there's barely any story. But that's not what this game is about. It's about using your brain and besting your enemies and the dungeon. Woop.

reviewText: I didn't know what to expect from this game, I only knew it belonged to a genre that diverges from what I usually play, but a few minutes in and I was in love with it. The secrets, the combat, the atmosphere, it sucked me in and I just had to complete it, and so I did. I'll share my experience now.\n\nAbout it's mechanics, you control a party of 4 characters. You're able customize their race, class, attributes and set custom portraits, I myself made an epic party with my closest friends. The battle formation is a square, so 2 characters lead and the others stay in the back, this encouraged me to balance my party members with melee or ranged attacks. The combat happens in real time and you can only move in tiles, each character have two available slots that you can place weapons, potions or other items into, you click these slots to perform actions, ones that depending on your char skills may cool-down" faster. ( One of my chars had max level sword ability
date: so he could strike twice as fast ). I enjoyed the combat A LOT

reviewText: No surprises here.  This is a classic dungeon crawl with some modern touches to it and a hell of a lot less typing.  In the vein of some really old-school games like Bard's Tale, Wizardry, and even Ultima Undeworld, this is an 80s-style RPG.\n\nThankfully, the devs were kind enough to provide an auto-mapping system, but if you want to go hardcore, they've allowed you to do that, too (bust out some grid paper).  Lots of secrets to find, some brutal difficulty at times, and some fun but none-too-hard puzzles will challenge you as you attempt to escape the dungeon.  Oh, and it's loaded with monsters.

reviewText:
If i could describe Legend of Grimrock in one word, it would be grueling. Yet this isn't necessarily a negative. The is a constant trek through a single dungeon, with little respite or change in scenary. You constantly have to worry about health, energy and food while fighting enemies, evading traps and solving puzzles. But it feels rewarding in a way. You really need to pay attention and work out scenarios to go foward. Though an obstacle may seem impossible at first: an unbeatable enemy encounter or an unsolvable puzzle, all you gotta do is step back, prepare and use quick wits to get past it. Time and time again you'll pull through in the search of the next floor or secret loot.
The controls are a little awkward at first, especially the rune-based magic system, but I feel it's part of the charm. The combat is simple, but requires you to be quick and composed while paying attention to enemy patterns. The puzzles do a lot with very little, simple switches and floor pads are used to create some clever riddles without delving into Myst or La-Mulana tier arcanery.
The biggest drawback would be the low production values, due to the small developer. There are only 3 tilesets for the dungeon, one of which you barely see. The main menu theme is great, but the actual game is mostly one ambient track, which is effective for building atmosphere but can get tiring after awhile.
Overall, LoG is a great game for those wanting a tribute to the old school dungeon crawlers like Eye of the Beholder, or anyone wanting a somewhat challenging change of pace.

reviewText:
Classic D&D squares! Heavy class based characters! Dice rolling!
LoG is basically D&D on screen. You move according to the squares on the floor, so basically in only predetermined steps. Enemies will also move the same as you.

Game tends to be puzzle heavy. Every puzzle, is aquainted with a scroll giving a hint towards solving it. You attack by clicking on your character's weapons and continue moving forward. You will have to maintain spells, items, weapons so on and so forth. No actual game bosses just the end game stuff (WHICH IS HILARIOUS AND AWESOME)

Too bad there's no New Game Plus to restart your old characters, but you can reuse them on community created maps.
Uses Steam Workshop. Music is outstanding. Would kill aga... err play again.

reviewText:
LoG is a grid style dungeon crawler that has revived the genre from its dying lineage from such games like 80's Dungeon Master.  This 13 floor, heavy puzzled, medium combat gameplay title does an excellent job at presenting new comers and old to the maze like dungeon of the Mountain of Grimrock.  Most of the puzzles work around pushing lose stones that protrude out from the walls and the combat style is of dancing around in a grid motion around the enemy.  There is no tank and spank strategy here unless playing on easy difficulty.

The game will take 20+ hours to complete depending on whether or not you spend the time to do the puzzles and/or find all the missing treasures that can be used for achievements or just upgrading you characters with better equipment.  The graphics are well done and the animation is quite well too.  There is an unlockable character that you must find in the dungeon which will let you run a new game once found with all new traits that will be different compared to the games regular 4 person party you've played with.  If enjoyed this alone is great replay value that extends the life even further to this gem.

Looking for a great grid style dungeon crawler look no further to The Legend of Grimrock!

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: What a fun little game this is! It is a very lightweight game which offers a surprising amount of dungeon crawling enjoyment! I think it's beauty lies in it's simplicity - it's basically just a 2D grid environment with 3D perspective graphics. Your party of 4 adventurers take up one tile and can only move one tile at a time either north, south, east or west. Combat is basically hack n slash but there is quite a bit of timing involved and strategy with how you use your 2 'front row' characters who can melee directly as opposed to the 2 'back row' characters who can either use ranged attacks/magic or perks to do melee attacks from afar. But sometimes you might find yourself cornered where monsters surround you and take big bites out of your typically soft back row guys.\n\nThere are alot of interesting puzzles some of which can drive you mad trying to figure them out! I really also like how food plays into the game (your guys need to eat!) and how items are very scarce.

reviewText:
Having played 'Dungeon Master' back in the early 90's, I was delighted to see a game based on that style but with modern graphics. So, when the game came on sale I instantly bought it. So, what did I think?

A really big WELL DONE! It takes me back to my childhood, playing Dungeon Master and other titles like it with my dad. The nostalgia instantly washed over me, bathing me in that happy feeling. The game is simple in its execution and layout, but does employ various puzzles the deeper you travel into the game, making you think. Combat is good and easy to manage.
There is an absence of speech in the game. By that I mean that the four prisoners you command do not engage with each other or say anything. The enemies don't seem to either. Not a problem as it's not that kind of game but at times when the only sound is your footsteps it can get boring. This may have worked twenty years ago but not now in 2015.

All in all a great game and a great homage to those early dungeon crawlers.

7/10

reviewText: Absolutely brilliant.\n\nLegend of Grimrock brings back to life an old genre of games I am not too familiar with. While it does use some oldfashion gameplay mechanics (like tile based movement) the game does not feel old in anyway. The gameplay is surprisingly clever and engaging. The real time, tile based combat creates an interesting challange forcing the player to dance around navigating in panic the well designed dungeons. It is not an easy game but the challange is fair and rewarding. The puzzles in the game and very creative and quite often challenging. Add to that the great atmosphere and it is a must try.

reviewText: LoG harkens back to classic turn/grid based Dungeon Crawlers with both superb graphics, gameplay and even freelook.  Don't be fooled by the trailer and teaser videos though.  You can play through the game at that speed but you will almost definitely get killed if you try to rush through it.  Take your time and don't charge head-first into enemies.  Watch out for traps...and use them to your advantage too!  Enemies will trigger spikes and trapdoors as well.\nIf you're a fan of old school dungeon crawlers, it's definitely worth the price but if you can, get it during a sale or watch out for game bundles featuring LoG.

reviewText: Absolutely brilliant.\n\nLegend of Grimrock brings back to life an old genre of games I am not too familiar with. While it does use some oldfashion gameplay mechanics (like tile based movement) the game does not feel old in anyway. The gameplay is surprisingly clever and engaging. The real time, tile based combat creates an interesting challange forcing the player to dance around navigating in panic the well designed dungeons. It is not an easy game but the challange is fair and rewarding. The puzzles in the game and very creative and quite often challenging. Add to that the great atmosphere and it is a must try.

reviewText: LoG harkens back to classic turn/grid based Dungeon Crawlers with both superb graphics, gameplay and even freelook.  Don't be fooled by the trailer and teaser videos though.  You can play through the game at that speed but you will almost definitely get killed if you try to rush through it.  Take your time and don't charge head-first into enemies.  Watch out for traps...and use them to your advantage too!  Enemies will trigger spikes and trapdoors as well.\nIf you're a fan of old school dungeon crawlers, it's definitely worth the price but if you can, get it during a sale or watch out for game bundles featuring LoG.

But yeah I fully recommend this and the sequel. It gives me that itch to play it when I stop and in my books that makes it a great game"

reviewText:
The title implies three things about this game: That it is legendary, that it is grim, and that there may possibly be rocks in it somewhere.  On these 3 implications, it does not disappoint.

LOG is a 1st-person ARPG, in which the player controls 4 adventurers accused of crimes and sentenced to trial by giant, mountain-dungeon. They are flung hell for breakfast into the dungeon, and must escape.

The game is an homage to old dungeon crawlers of yore, and has some game design to intentionally reflect this, you can only move in one of the cardinal directions at any given time, and a lot of combat is frantically strafing out of opponent's attacks while fumbling with the spell system or attempting to drink a potion.

While the intentional complications can be irritating at times, the game is still quite enjoyable, brimming with traps, secrets, and monsters.

If you like a good old fashioned dungeon crawl, LOG is the game for you.

reviewText:
Fun, old-school dungeon crawl in the style of Eye of the Beholder.  Despite the fact that it gives you options to play on 'Normal' or 'Hard', I'm finding that 'Normal' is quite challenging enough!

For difficult encounters, I suggest kiting. In LoG, that means running away while throwing stuff (including spells). Torches can be thrown if you run out of more pointy things.

Rest often. Food seems to be pretty plentiful, and it seems that actions (like fighting and exploring) make you more hungry than resting.

reviewText:
Very good for classic gamers. If you ever played Eye of the Beholder or Lands of Lore, you'll feel right at home. :)

The premise is similar: here, you have a grid-based first person RPG with real time battles. You control 4 characters, 2 in the front row and 2 in the back, and explore a huge dungeon full of monsters and puzzles. Its VERY similar to the first Eye of the Beholder, but with a better interface and an automap feature (that can be disabled, if you feel like it).

The graphics are great, the enemies are varied and the challenge is quite high. And the puzzles... Ahh, those can range from I had to think a little" to "WHAT THE HELL DO I DO HERE?!?!". And believe-me: they are FUN

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock
A 3D take on a RPD board kind of style. The game is based in a dungeon which is situated inside a mountain, Your 4 characters are prisoners and your only chance of survival is to escape the dungeon.

You slowly progress floor by floor down a grid style environment. It is in a way turn based but it does it very well. The controls are very easy to learn and everything is taught to you pretty early in the game.

The art style  is very typical of a dungeon rpg you have the vines hanging from the walls and the cobblestone bricks but for a dungeon it can look very pretty the monsters especially have been made very well with their stationary movements and attacks.

One of the only issues I had with this game was that some of the puzzles I just didnt understand or they just werent obvious so I had to check some youtube videos but that could just be down to my own incompetence.

I rate it a 8/10

Definately check out the sequel as well!

I recommend this because it's really rather good - but there's an issue you should be aware of - difficulty.

Easy is trivial and never goes beyond moderate - Normal starts OK but gets rather harder than yo might expect.

reviewText:
Recently, I've played a bunch of puzzles games and a good friend told me to play Grimrock because of the puzzles... But to me, it was mostly the gameplay that I really liked about this one. I really loved fighting in this game. It started so slow. I wasn't even sure I was liking it at first, but after an hour or so. Bam. I was in. I was in it for good. Nothing else really interested me. All I wanted was to level up, gain abilities, gear my characters, kill more stuff, walk further, discover more secrets, and of course get confused by the puzzles.

Grimrock is a perfect example of a typical indie game that takes an old 90's (even maybe late 80's) gameplay design and redo it in our modern era. It is kind of a slow game. Every time you move is tile by tile and when you attack or so you click on the attack, do it on front of you, wait for the cooldown and repeat. But in the end, it's only like if it would be a turn based combat system, but sometimes, you can get a turn faster than your opponent. Also, it gets pretty hard. You can facetank the first level or 2 but the gameplay gets pretty crazy pretty fast. You discover new types of weapons and new monsters. You have to kite them in order to survive. They are hard. You have to act fast and think fast too. You are not always fighting in the same environment. It's a really great mechanic. Any limitations you may have, the monsters have them too. You have to learn their pattern, and execute yours.

There is just so much stuff to discover. The whole world is begging you to find the hidden stuff everywhere. You will have to face really hard puzzles just to keep going on the main tract. They always comes with clues, so it's really fair. But some of them are really obnoxious and if you are not in it for the puzzles, you might want to consider looking for a guide. Or maybe just relax and take notes for an hour or two because some of the puzzles really require you to do so.

It might be a good idea to look for character guides too before starting to play. The way you build and play your character really matters. Like you might completely ruin your run if you put stats in stuff you end up not using. The game gets pretty hard later. You have to have good gear and especially specialized characters. So if you consider playing, but you only have time for 1 playthrough. Do a bit of research, look out recommendations, and get the game because it is really fun to play.

I give it 8/10. I can't wait to play the second one !

reviewText:
BEATEN!
Total playtime for playthrough - about 14 hours.
Classes chosen: 2 Minatour Melee/ 2 Wizards (ice/fire primarys)

Legends of Grimrock is a VERY old-school dungeon crawl experience. Tile-by-tile this game is tense and full of failure (but topped with rousing successes). It is hard but fun. It also, interestingly, includes a lot of environmental puzzles. On one or two occassions, the genre sorta made these a bit harder than they might otherwise be, but overall they are not an issue.

PROS:
- Old school dungeon crawling
- Character creation. Too many mixes to have them all.
- Good monster/level design
- A good challange
- Steam workshop! Even play new dungeons with existing characters.

Cons:
- Some time-based puzzles can be annoying
- Can be a bit difficult for those impatient.
- No outdoor spaces (See LOG2)

Would certainly recommend

reviewText:
You know how sometimes people try to remake or update or mondernize something and they fail miserably? Like e.g. trying to remake Total Recall or Conan the barbarian or trying to modernize Simon the sorcered (as in 3D) or reimagin Star Trek?

Well... this is NOT like that. This is more something like... get The Elder Scrolls 1 and 2 and rebuild them wiith Skyrim's engine sort of thing.

If you like dungeon crawlers of the eye of the beholder flavor, lands of lore flavor, bards tale flavor (you get the idea) then you will lose it with this one because it is one of those games, built for modern machines. The gameplay is identical and this is a HUGE pro.

Do NOT skip this game . It is absolutely fantastic.

reviewText: A classic RPG in the style of Eye of the Beholder and other first-person RPGs from the early '90s. There's about 25 hours of content here, and its all worthwhile. Much of the game involves trap puzzles. There is no grind or repetition here -- your character will progress at a reasonable rate to match the challenges of each level, and each level offers new and interesting challenges. The game has a retro feel with modern graphics, and doesn't drag on forever like many other RPGs. Much of the fun involves hunting for secrets (and there are many).\n\nThere's essentially no replay value here, but your first playthrough will give you more than your money's worth. There are no unskippable cutscenes to destroy the fun.

reviewText:
Excellent dungeon crawler, it brings together nice visuals with classic gameplay. Reminded me of Portal but with a D&D twist.

+Graphics, dungeons, and monsters all look great.
+3 classes to choose from (Fighter/Mage/Rogue), each with different skills
+Create your own party of 4 characters, even import portraits if you like (takes a little know-how)
+A decent variety of skill choices and couple weapon choices per class, with adaptability through leveling
+Story and puzzle elements blend together well, some challenging puzzles
+Unique spellcasting system using runes like a combination lock
+Lots of secrets to uncover and feel rewarded with both equipment and achievements
+Probably the most impressive part is that it comes with a dungeon editor - play others' or make your own!

-Few default portrait choices for characters
-No animations or models for your characters themselves, no voiced dialogue
-No cross-classing for any skills/abilities
-No shops or salvage system makes looting feel pointless/lackluster at times
-Availability of some items unnecessarily punishes some skill choices
-Spell system can become more of a chore in combat as the game goes on

reviewText:
LEGEND OF GRIMROCK
A first-person dungeon crawler set in a series of underground labyrinths, filled with monsters, puzzles and traps.

Rating 7/10

A throwback to the early 90s role-playing games like Eye of the Beholder, Ultima Underworld and Stonekeep. Whilst in many ways Legend of Grimrock is a homage to those early games it's worth buying not just for nostalgia but because it's a great game in it's own right.

In updating the classic formula they haven't changed much, grid-based movement, advancing one tile at a time with 90 degree turns. The party consists of four different characters spread across three classes, the fighters in the front row and the more vulnerable mage and Rogue in the back row. The two in the front row will deal the most damage and take the most damage via melee combat, the two characters in the back row can use magic and ranged attacks. It's a fine balance and timing is key in order to keep your party alive.

Combat suffers from the same limitations as it did in the games Grimrock is trying to re-create, wait for the enemy to enter the tile in front of you before unleashing all of your attacks then back away or strafe sideways before they have a chance to return damage. Rinse and repeat. There are obviously times this strategy doesn't always work such as being surrounded by three or more enemies or backing into a dead end but it's the strategy you'll end up using the most. It worked back in the 90s and it still works now.

There is a story loosely attached but it's not really important, this is a dungeon crawler at heart and the fun comes from fighting your way through and solving puzzles in each new level of the dungeon. There are no quests to speak of other than to survive the dungeon. During the game you pick up clues and lore via letters left by a previous prisoner called Toorum, it's a simple but effective way of building up some atmosphere and history to the adventure.

It's a bit too easy and a bit too short. I completed the game twice unlocking all achievements, completing my second play through on Hard Boiled and Doin' It Old School and even then I completed it with little effort. Aside from making the game longer I felt it would have benefited from a few NPCs, something Stonekeep did to great effect. It would have broken up the game play a bit and offered something different. However these are fairly minor disappointments to what is otherwise a superb game.

Looking forward to Legend of Grimrock 2.

reviewText: This game is very well done. Great enemy variety, good graphics, challenging puzzles, spooky atmosphere, a combat system that is basic (except when it comes to magic, in which case, have fun finding all those spell combonations), and a truly amazing level creator which provides infinite replayability via your own creations and those of your friends. Not to mention the amazing one song soundtrack (That menu will be the best menu you've ever listened to, my friend). If you like this style of game, this will be the game of your dreams that you will never get tired of. Otherwise, it's still a fun experience that can at least get you a few hours of gameplay before you get tired of all those spiders and crabs. Even if you only aim to play through the main story once, that's at least fifteen hours of gameplay right there (or so I'm led to believe, I've never beat it; gave up after the fire demons).

reviewText:
In The Legend of Grimrock you control a party of four thrown into a dungeon atop a mountain and have to explore down through level after level looking for the exit to escape

I really enjoyed exploring this dungeon full of traps, monsters, puzzles, secrets and treasure. The graphics are very nice if a bit repetitive and the style of play was very refreshing as it's so different to anything else I've played in a long time.

It's a great benefit that the game also supports user made content so there's a ton of value for money and hundreds of hours of content if you want to explore more.

reviewText:
This game is a freaking blast. I've been running just the main dungeon they start you with, not a downloaded one off the workshop, and it is the epitome of classic dungeon simulation. The puzzles are challenging, the combat isn't just point and click, the aesthetic really matches the environment, makes me feel really immersed, and the story is subtle yet intruiging.

Gameplay - 9/10 - Really fits it's genre well, quality game
Graphics - 8/10 - The lighting and textures are fantastic, but on one creature I laughed out loud when I saw it, it just looked so silly. Nice to look at though.
Story - 7/10 - Despite not really being a story-driven game, the light story shoe-horned in seems to push you forward with a certain sense of uncertainty.
Replayability - x/10 - I'd assume playing the first dungeon would be interesting to run multiple times, see how fast you can do the whole thing again, but the true playability comes from the custom-made dungeons, which will add time spent on the game as long as the community keeps making them.

Overall - 8.5/10. Great dungeon game.

reviewText: If you think point-and-click games can't be scary as hell, then you're wrong. The atmosphere in Legend of Grimrock is perfect, and anyone who is a fan of RPGs, tabletop, or old-school-gaming will love it. Puzzles abound, awesome combat, and generally a really nice tribute to old crawler games.

reviewText:
A great tribute to oldschool dungeon crawlers (the kind I grew up with in the late 80s and early 90s).  I think it definitely helps to have been a fan of tabletop stuff like D&D and Warhammer (which I'm thankful to my father for, for raising me on) to really appreciate how cool this game is.
It's just as much about strategy and timing as it is hunting for loot.  A nice mix between easy, almost obvious puzzles and puzzles that will have you face-palming in frustration.

If you're like me and you were raised on high fantasy, classic computer games and tabletop strategy, the nostalgia factor will be very high.

reviewText:
Buy this if you have no life. Otherwise, you'll end up not loosing it. This game will keep you chained to the chair for 40(ish) hours.
The story is terrible and dissapointingly blunt, BUT the gameplay is unbelievable. Cleptomaniacs will profit from their addiction (you'll remember theese words when you reach lvl 10), nerds will enjoy remembering the casting of every spell and mindless hack'n'slashers will enjoy dispatching hordes of enemies throught this mindconsuming dungeon.
Legend of Grimrock will challenge and improve your intelect and taunt your wisdom.
Really worth a couple of Euros. :)

reviewText:
Easily a 9/10.
Definitely worth the full price.

At first I bought this game during a steam sale and forgot about it, but after burning myself out of a couple of other RPGs I noticed I had this game still practically untouched. The combat is fun and interesting, its fast paced enough to keep you on your toes, but slow enough to give you time to do things like brew a potion on the fly or swap out weapons. The controls can take a little getting used to, but its overall simplicity is a godsend in an age of Menus: the RPG. It would not have much replayability if not for the robust steam workshop integration. The game is pretty light on the story and allows you do get right to the heart of this Dungeon-Crawler without worrying too much about the details.
Overall an excellent experience.

reviewText: Legend of Grimrock is a 3D first person tile-based dungeon crawler with real-time combat. Blending elements of Wizardry, Ultima Underworld(s) and Arx Fatalis it's a solid entry into a very small corner of the RPG world where releases are few and far between.\n\nYou begin as a party of four prisoners thrown into a dungeon atop a mountain. A place, as the game cleverly puts it, Only remembered when things need to be discarded or forgotten." There are no towns

reviewText:
If you remember the old classics like Eye of the Beholder, you owe it to yourself to play this game.  If you've ever been interested in old-school dungeon crawlers but never got a chance to play them because you were either too young or they're too aged for you, your problems have been solved.

It shines of polish and is by far one of the best PC games I have played in the last 5 years.

If you do buy it, grab it on the official website for a DRM free version along with a Steam key.  Yeah, they're one of those very rare developers that care.

Also, 4 people made this game.  FOUR.  Unbelievable.  So much love put into this game.

Grimrock is worth every penny, hands down.  I love it and you will too.

Oh, and there's a full modding community for it recreating all the old dungeon crawler games, like EotB.  Yeah, amazing.

Upon first watching somebody play this game, I found myself immediately going to buy it as soon as I could.
The game, while lacking a fulfilling ending, is quite well made, and has a large amount of replayability in hidden secrets and modding tools which allow for new experiences to be made by the community.

Even though he disliked the genre of the game, Legend of Grimrock still managed to entice him right up until the end with the mixture of logic puzzles, fair combat, and hidden secrets.

reviewText:
Awesome game!  A throwback to old tile-based dungeon crawler games, this game is real-time, difficult, and bleak.

You control a whole party of 4 adventurers that are forced by their ankle chains to stand on the same square.  There are tons of puzzles as well as tough monster fights.  Secret rooms everywhere!  Your characters need to eat occasionally or they start to recieve negative effects, forcing you to keep moving deeper towards your own doom.

Everything seems well balanced, though it is balanced towards difficulty.  In order to do well in combat, you are expected to perform a ballet dance, attacking the enemies from the side and sidestepping them before they turn to face you.  You will probably end up dying a lot, so save often.  If you want a real challenge, there is an option to turn off the map, forcing you to use graph paper to map out the dungeon as you go.

The game is said to last at least 10 hours, and a level editor and mod support are coming soon.

reviewText: This games is awesome! A true dungeon crawler, with puzzles, traps, and dungeon dwellers. The rich story unravels as you play, giving you a reason to want to find your way out of the dungeon, not to mention see what's waiting for you at the bottom. It's nice to have a decent range of character customization, without spending hours figuring out what you want your characters to look like. You can choose portraits for your characters, but ultimately their stats and bonuses are going to be more important in this game. I tried it out for the first time and ended up playing for 5 hours straight!

You can choose portraits for your characters, but ultimately their stats and bonuses are going to be more important in this game. I tried it out for the first time and ended up playing for 5 hours straight!

reviewText: Do not underestimate this game: it is tough. Even on easy, the puzzles become daunting, the monsters brutal, and your party's resources frighteningly scarce. If you're not careful to level up your characters efficiently right out of the gates you'll find yourself trapped in grinding mode until you're able to progress...but be warned: your food dwindles at an alarming rate and is every bit as elusive as any other form of aid. It's a no-joke type situation, and a person would do well to get into this with the mindset of committing to a hardcore adventure.\n\nNonetheless, I find the challenge a good thing. It's refreshing to have to think in a video game again and quite rewarding when you manage to proceed to another floor. You can spend a huge amount of time playing this game too--plenty of levels, lots of achievements, tons of brain teasing puzzles, plenty of weapons and gear to scavenge and disburse amongst your characters. While not for the faint of heart, this game gets my thumbs-up.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock should be seen as definitely proof that Finns are actually good for something despite their well known insanity, or perhaps because of it.

Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the core of the RPG genre. Stat based dungeon crawling. No mouse twitching skills required. No pseudo-choices that have no gameplay effects. No dialog pretending to be grey.

This is pure RPG gameplay. You create your party and fight through a dungeon of monsters finding new equipment and leveling up their skills and stats as you go along.

Despite the fairly oldschool grid based gameplay it is a pretty game, with good sounds, great exploration, hard to find secrets and frustrating puzzles. The combat might seem simple from the outside but movement will play a major part in the harder battles and particularly on the harder difficulties.

If there was something bad to say about this game it was a relatively short main campaign but the addition of Steam Workshop fixed that.

A great buy.

reviewText:
One of my favorite indie games

A grind based dungeon crawler, aparently based on some old school games ive never played, but if they are anywhere near as good as legend of grimrock ive missed out

Within the game you control a party of 4 characters at the same time and move in first person through square grind based dungeons, the game has a great degree of micromanagement, you use the different attacks of your party members individually, they suffer from different status effects, they all have their own stats and they all suffer from hunger and carrying limitations, not to mention since your characters are set up in a square formation within the square grind you are on attacks from different directions affect different party members, learning to balance all of this is pivotal to success

the dungeons in this game are all well designed with clever puzzles and some nice settings. The combat in the game is for the most part decent, it can get a little boring agaisnt single enemies, since running around em is usually enough, but when multiple enemies are present it becomes really challenging, since you must maneuver the environment skillfully to avoid getting trapped and having your weakest party members killed. Your party members can belong to 4 races and 3 different classes, each with their own characteristics, the mage class is a standout, offering the most interesting and challenging combat of all classes. The game in general is very hard but fair, with only a couple of traps and situations id describe as cheap

When it comes to graphics, they are somewhat simple but pleasing to the eye, with an adequate amount of detail on screen and a good art direction, its understandably claustrophobic but this goes well with the game's setting and mechanics, i guess one flaw on this regard is the fact we are dealing with the overly familiar middle ages fantasy setting here

the game has a very long campaign, it took me around 19 hours to finish the main campaign and i didnt even find all the secrets, you can start a new game with different party configurations and the game has steam workshop support with over 700 custom dungeons, this thing has some serious replay value

fantastic game overall, my mayor complain is the fact a game like this begs for randomization and yet it has none, it could really benefit for random dungeons with random loot, random spells, random enemies in random locations, but well i guess the game couldnt have these brilliant puzzles otherwise, and the steam workshop support does alleviate this shortcoming a bit

reviewText: I used to have a board game called Hero Quest when I was a kid.  I loved it! Coincidentally, I also began to take a second look at dungeon crawlers.  Before this time, my largest exposure to first person RPGs of the like was Bard's Tale and I hated that game.  I bought Eye of the Beholder" and "Shining in the Darkness" back then.  I dabbled with them
date: but quickly moved onto other RPGs.\nFast forward twelve years later and I picked up and finally beat Shining
recommended: giving it more respect and reigniting an appreciation for that style of RPG.  Two years after Shining
hoursPlayed: I beat Phantasy Star.  Two years after Phantasy Star
voteText: I beat Shadowgate and now Legend of Grimrock.\nI love top ten lists

votesFunny: but the effects do make certain reflective surfaces appear artificially shiny.  Gameplay is pretty straightforward.  Find better gear and attack bad guys.  The battle system is very simplistic as it really just comes down to right clicking.  The joy in combat actually comes from side stepping and dodging enemies to smack them.  It really is pleasing to be able to pull this off flawlessly after some practice. If done correctly
commentsCount: you can go floors before even getting hit.\nI played on Hard and Old School mode and it hurt me emotionally. I ended up getting lost several times
column16: despite best efforts at maps and some enemies made me swear bad things against their offspring.\nThe story is nearly nonexistent

column19: is what is it comes down to.  The final boss was unexpected until you got down to the 12th floor and the battle wasn't overly difficult, but was a tad too long as I would dish out a few hits, drop down to the lower floor, heal, save, repeat.   The artwork for the ending is well done and I was surprised that a game this well made was done by four people.  It's worth a play if you're into this type of thing.
