reviewText: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5JHMsyOgDlU\n\nLegend of Grimrock is a dungeon crawling role playing game with an oldschool heart but a modern execution. A group of prisoners are sentenced to certain death by exiling them to the secluded Mount Grimrock for vile crimes they may or may not have committed. Unbeknownst to their captors, the mountain is riddled with ancient tunnels, dungeons and tombs built by crumbled civilizations long perished now. If they ever wish to see daylight again and reclaim their freedom the ragtag group of prisoners must form a team and descend through the mountain, level by level. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
Proof you don't need a D&D license and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ soap opera story. Just make a great game and leave it at that.

Grimrock is a modern dungeon crawler that puts age old mechanics to good use. Your goal is very simple. Guide a party through a nasty dungeon while avoiding traps, fighting monsters, collecting better equipment and leveling up.

The game is comfortable and easy to play despite the difficulty ramping up after the first few levels. For those who enjoy exploring and getting lost there's an option to switch off the automap. There are secret areas aplenty and some puzzles require a bit of thinking. Most of the time it's enough to just look everywhere and figure out how to make use of things like pressure plates, teleports or timing mechanisms.

The enemies are quite cruel and your party will become overmatched pretty quickly. Fortunately it's possible to close gates and block off some areas, and it's not necessary to kill everything. If you must kill things to progress, usually there's a way to make use of the dungeon itself and make it easier.

I have played a lot of dungeon crawlers and have liked some of them. Ishar 3 was good though i never finished it. I loved Captive but finished it even less... Albion was interesting, though not exactly a classic example, and neither was Whale's Voyage. Hired Guns was incredible for it's time and hard as hell for good measure. Never could get into Dungeon Master or Eye of the Beholder much, though EoB was ok. Anvil of Dawn was pretty impressive. I think there's a few games i forgot, but anyway...

Maybe i'm weak for Hired Guns a bit more but Legend of Grimrock is the most awesome of the bunch!

reviewText:
I never was much for games that require parties. To be honest, I didn't even like the Dragon Age series. However, this game is the exception to the rule. There's just something charmin and magical about the way this game works, as you and your merry team of four carefully collect the scarce resources around you and master difficult puzzles.

Pros:
+Old-school charm
+Good puzzles
+Calm, but engaging combat
+Good creature and level design

Neutral:
Story is a bit subtle.

Cons:
-Old-school difficulty
-Sometimes you need a walkthrough

Overall, I strongly recommend this game. It's a blast to play, and a good way to simultaneously unwind and put your brain to good use, too.

reviewText: The Legend of Grimrock is a fun and entertaining dungeon crawler role-playing game that really captures the core of the genre. Elements from Dungeons & Dragons and like games have been incorporated into the Legend of Grimrock and with great success. Coming from a person who normally doesn't like dungeon crawlers, this is definitely an amazing game! As if it could get any better, a dungeon editor is available, which allows players to build their own customizeable dungeons and share their creations with other players. This game contains many features for the player to explore and customize, as well as stimulating puzzles that can really boggle your mind. Although the puzzle aspect of the game pervades and dominates over the action or dialogue, the Legend of Grimrock is nevertheless an exciting RPG that revitalizes the dungeon crawler genre!

reviewText:
Bought this a good while back when it was on sale with the sequel for about $8, just found the time to start playing it today.
Being a huge D&D and RPG fan but having never really played any of the dungeon-crawler genre, wasn't sure what to expect. 2 hours in, I find myself loving this game. Its not a button-masher like some RPGs (Skyrim, Dark Alliance, etc), its a lot more subtle, and a lot more intelligent. All kinds of little tricks, traps, and hidden secrets that you have to look for yourself, there are few if any real hints. It makes me think, and backtrack to double-check something, and think some more, and its awesome.
I would recommend this game to anyone who like RPGs, as a change of pace and a breath of fresh air. This was really well done, and I'm looking forward to the more challenging levels and the entire sequel, which I've been told is even better than this.

Protip, pick up rocks, you will need them.

reviewText: This game is amazing, I really like it, I put a few hours into it so far nd I am loving every minute of it. The combat is very well done, and although its turn based, the fact you can move around to avoid damage is very good. Also having the 2 front line characters and 2 back line characters makes it so you can strategically place your characters the way you want. I made to fighters  with one being really tanky and the other one having a bit more damage to go in my front line and a mage and rogue for my back line, and I find it a very good setup. Theres 4 races. Human, Minotaur, Insectoid, and Lizard man, and each has their own strengths and weakness. Human is balanced all around, but isn't the best at one specific class, Minotaur is more tanky, but has low dexterity so they have a low starting hit rate, making them good tanks, Lizard man has high dexterity, but lower strength, making them better rogues, and Insectoid has higher willpower, making them better mages.\nOf course you don't have to make a character based off their stats. You could for example make a Lizard man fighter that has high dexterity, but lower strength, or a Minotaur rogue that has more health and damage, but hits less,  or all humans for all around classes. It may not be as reccomended, but would work. Also honestly the game allows you to import your own photos, only the specs make up each race, so you could essentially have 4 anime chicks if you really wanted. Overall it is a great game, and is very fun, and addicting. It has great gameplay, great sound deseign with the ambient soundtrack, pretty decent graphics that are pretty enough, but also not too demanding for those that have lower end pcs can play, engaging puzzles and the enviroment is nice, even if it is just a dungeon it really fits the game, and although there isn't much to the story, it is just enough to fit the style of this game. I would highly reccomend this game. 10/10

reviewText: This game is amazing, I really like it, I put a few hours into it so far nd I am loving every minute of it. The combat is very well done, and although its turn based, the fact you can move around to avoid damage is very good. Also having the 2 front line characters and 2 back line characters makes it so you can strategically place your characters the way you want. I made to fighters  with one being really tanky and the other one having a bit more damage to go in my front line and a mage and rogue for my back line, and I find it a very good setup. Theres 4 races. Human, Minotaur, Insectoid, and Lizard man, and each has their own strengths and weakness. Human is balanced all around, but isn't the best at one specific class, Minotaur is more tanky, but has low dexterity so they have a low starting hit rate, making them good tanks, Lizard man has high dexterity, but lower strength, making them better rogues, and Insectoid has higher willpower, making them better mages.\nOf course you don't have to make a character based off their stats. You could for example make a Lizard man fighter that has high dexterity, but lower strength, or a Minotaur rogue that has more health and damage, but hits less,  or all humans for all around classes. It may not be as reccomended, but would work. Also honestly the game allows you to import your own photos, only the specs make up each race, so you could essentially have 4 anime chicks if you really wanted. Overall it is a great game, and is very fun, and addicting. It has great gameplay, great sound deseign with the ambient soundtrack, pretty decent graphics that are pretty enough, but also not too demanding for those that have lower end pcs can play, engaging puzzles and the enviroment is nice, even if it is just a dungeon it really fits the game, and although there isn't much to the story, it is just enough to fit the style of this game. I would highly reccomend this game. 10/10

reviewText:
(Adaptation of my Grimrock 2 review.)

Getting lost in this huge dungeon is so great. Even in the age of Witcher 3, this game shows that grid-based movement can still be fun. I have a hard time explaining why but here are some possible factors:
- Enemies feel more menacing because you can't circle-strafe them, play with aggro range or exploit pathfinding bugs against them like in most free movement rpgs/fpss. So the dungeon feels more claustrophobic and menacing... I definitely don't feel that in Skyrim dungeons.
- Mapping out the dungeon square by square and paying close attention to your environment for secret buttons and switches feels great, and it's not the typical modern RPG experience. A free movement game can hardly hide a button somewhere on a wall and expect you to find it, here with the constrained views it works.
- The grid system allows for some very smart puzzles, I have to admit I sometimes give up and consult a walkthrough, but I enjoy their presence nonetheless!

And you get to control (read: juggle) 4 characters, so four times the RPG goodness!

All in all, you'll like it if you liked old-school RPGs like Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder and Lands of Lore: Throne of Chaos. But if you haven't played those games you should try it anyways! You might very well find that grid-based movement is a bit like pixel art: originally born of technical limitations, it can still bring a unique and interesting twist to a game.

Once you're done with this one check out Grimrock 2! It's bigger, more varied visually and less linear. The modding scene is also flourishing for both games, though I suspect mods for the second game must be better, modders have more material and a more advanced engine to work with.

reviewText: A great and well rounded game that has just the right amout of difficulty and unforgiveness. Reminds me a lot of table top Dungeons and Dragons. My only complaint is there is hardly a punishment for death. When a character dies they can still hold torches and their inventory can still be opened. If I were to change something about this game it would be that dead characters can't hold torches(or provide light in any way) and also make it so either the dead character's inventory becomes locked or their inventory is split up into the other party members. Other than that I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys dungeons and dragons, dungeon crawlers, and even rogue likes. I give it a solid 9/10.

reviewText:
Starved for a good ole fashion dungeon crawl, I reallllly want to like this game...

Pros:
- Graphics are gorg

- Weapons seem to miss a sh!t-ton of the time, and are sparse and slow in coming

Surrrrrrie, but I feel a little cheated with the 95% love for this game...it's ok....just ok.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock is an accessible dungeon crawler with fun and engrossing puzzles; the kind of puzzles that aren't complicated but require a decent understanding of the point-and-click mechanics. Unfortunately most of the underwhelming puzzles require hugging the wall and hunting down hidden wall switches.

The RPG mechanics are pretty barebones. The combat consist of mindless clicking and side-stepping. You'll most likely never reach the end level class skills in your first playthough without excessive grinding. The only redeemable aspect of combat is the spellcasting system. In Grimrock, using magic spells require you enter the correct combinations of runes, as if you are dialing them on a keypad. Learning new rune combinations through the scrolls found in the dungeon is always an enjoyable treat.

I only beat the main campaign but it took me roughly 10 hours not counted on Steam as my internet connection was down for a period of time. The user submitted workshop dungeons could hypothetically add even more unique playtime with this but I haven't had a clue if they are as good as the main game. Grimrock is well worth the full price by itself, though.

One final note is that if you are of faint of heart you might not enjoy this game as it throws you a ton of creepy creatures that run around in the darkness of the dungeon.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So, you want an old school RPG adventure ? This is it ! Legend Of Grimrock starts you off with 4 prisoners, in a mountain, consisting of 13 levels. These levels are filled with puzzles, evil creatures, traps and more and, obviously, it gets increasingly difficult along the way.
However, the difficulty is a bit random at times. Near the end it took me literally minutes to take down one enemy, even though I had some proper spells and weapons. There are moments where you will be overwhelmed by quite a few enemies. Remember to save often, and try not to lose any of your party members before you reached the end of a level. I had to finish a level with just one rogue and it took me 3-4x longer than it should've.
The game can be finished in about 10-12 hours (in-game time) but in reality it should take you about twice as long.
You will die several times, and some puzzles require thinking, experimenting or just plain luck.
But despite the difficulty, I did have a great time with it !

[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText: Do you miss the dungeon-crawling of yore? Ever wished you could play games like Dungeon Master or Eye of the Beholder with modern design? Then Legend of Grimrock is the game for you!\n\nIn Grimrock you form a party of four people and explore a vast dungeon. The movement is tile-based and in real-time. You move with the keyboard and all other actions are done with the mouse, like in the classic dungeon crawlers. The overall game is pretty challenging and the combat at times is tough as nails when you fight against multiple enemies. The riddles and puzzles are very well designed (apart from 1-2) and will probably have you scratch your head quite a bit. There are no NPCs to talk with, no towns to sell your loot or anything like that - it's just your party and a dark, scary dungeon (although the game does have a story!). There will be an editor available eventually, allowing people to create and share their own dungeons! Give it a look, it's great!

reviewText:
A modern take on the old-school tile-based dungeon crawler, was something of a surprise hit. Blending a close to perfect mix of horror, suspense, mystery, puzzles, and combat, Legend of Grimrock enticed my inner adventurer. The game itself is quite enjoyable, the grim-dark atmosphere lends itself perfectly to the setting, and the tile-based movement adds an interesting mechanic to it all. The is a game where you will make mistakes, there’s no avoiding that, you will fumble and fall and lose party members and grumble as you backtrack to a crystal. You’ll jump and curse when spiders sneak up on you, groan and rage as traps trigger and surround you with enemies, and kick yourself for not saving more often. You’ll experiment in the skill tree and find out that you’ve invested in something useless, or that you’ve given points wrong, or expended one-use items on the wrong character. Sometimes you’ll wish you’d taken the other loot, or wondered what was in the other locked room, so you’ll reload and find out, then compare before reloading again and deciding. You’ll rage as monsters surround you, you’ll rage as you find a character suddenly out of ammo, mana, poisoned, or just plain dead. You’ll rage as you run from Ogres, you’ll rage as Fire Elementals hit your back-row characters, you’ll rage as you’re confronted with new horrors the dungeon has to offer. But most of all, you will rage at the puzzles.
The game does not hold your hand, which is both beautiful and mildly infuriating at times. There’s a lot of trial an error when it comes to solving puzzles, and you will die a lot trying. But that’s what this game is, a lot of trial and error. It can be harsh, but it’s never unfair, so long as you use your brain and save every 5 minutes. The only genuine complaint I have with the game is the inventory/loot system; space was simple to manage so long as you saved your sacks and boxes, but the weight mechanic was a little challenging at times, when I discover that the Kayran Nipple I just looted and put in a character’s inventory has weighed them down and has made the party slow as hell. What really got me was that there was no loot selling or anything like that, things just became obsolete and you had no reason to keep them, other than maybe convenient replacements for rocks.
All in all I love this game to death, and had that rare compulsion to play it every second I had free time, though the game is best enjoyed, in my opinion, in longer sessions. That way you remember all the little details you were going over and you don’t miss out on something. That being said, I went over the entire dungeon with a fine-toothed come and still managed to miss some secrets, as the statistics will tell you. Half-way through my first playthrough I realized my lizardman rogue was relatively useless when I could have just gone double fighter mage combo, since I had teched him into ranged and throwing. And that was a mistake. You MUST specialize your character if you want to survive, if you choose to go down swords, you stick with swords, if you want axes, don’t switch out for maces because you found one and it was better, and try to keep to one or two disciplines of magic.
For anyone who likes grim-dark fantasy, dungeon crawling, RPG’s, mystery, puzzles, and/or tile-based combat, Legend of Grimrock is definitely a must. Your inner loot-♥♥♥♥♥ will be pleased, your inner puzzler will be perplexed, and your inner adventurer will be grinning all the while. Enter Mount Grimrock, and make your way to the horrors within, best of luck.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock is a solid old-school rpg game for rpg fans, nostalgia seekers, and gamers that wish to flex their creative muscles.

The main story is about a band of 4 criminals who have commited treasonous crimes, and those crimes will only be pardoned if  they survive mount grimrock, a aincient nordic-looking cave atop a high moutain. The game sticks to its classic roots. There is a smooth and simple skill tree, races (that dont play too much of a part), and plenty of suprises and new foes to keep the game intresting. The game also supports Steam's workshop, to share and try out new dungeons. I had lots of fun scanning stone temple walls for hidden buttons, finding out new puzzles, such as a pressure plate that needs to be weighed down with a rock, in order to pass through.

Overall, I would recommend this game to alot of my friends, but the old-school genre isn't for everyone. If you are used to a game such as Dark Souls II or the Elder Scrolls V, this may not be for you.

My rating 8.5 / 10

Keeps you coming back for more!

reviewText:
This is how a dungeon crawler is done. It's really old school with lots of modern elements.

So, what's the story? Well, there sort of isn't a story, ok, yes, there is, but it's not so essential to the main plot. The plot is that three people accused of crimes are thrown into a dunegon and must escape. So they must survive while there are monsters everywhere, disgusting food, a strange dream that happens sometimes when you rest, creepy sounds and amazing atmosphere. The graphics add so much to the atmosphere too because they look very amazing and somehow this game runs very well on my terrible PC. I wish more games did that.

There are 3 main parts to this game and I will review each aspect one by one:

Combat

Puzzle Solving

Exploration

Combat-The combat in this game is an old school style one, you're party is in 4 people all linked together and you walk on square tiles. You have to gather up weapons from monsters, hidden rooms and exploring the place as so. The magic combat system and the magic system in general is you have to combine a certain combination of runes. You can find these combinations on scrolls which you find and by leveling up the certain types of skills in the game. Speaking of the skills, the skills are pretty much subclasses in classes. The 3 classes in this game are fighter, rouge and mage. (There's a fourth one too but you will have to discover that for yourself) Each class has different abilities, attributes, purposes, uses, etc. There's also traits you can have on each character. There's lots to choose from and some races have their own trait. The 4 races are Human, Minotaur, Lizardman and Insectoid. Each are good for their own class, like how the Lizardman makes a good rogue and how the minotaur makes a good fighter.

Puzzle solving-The puzzles in this game are diffucult. I had a LONG time trying to solve them. But after solving all of them, it was all worth it since it was fun and rewarding.

Exploration-Without exploration, I don't think this game would've been so great. There are TONS of secrets everywhere. Some are easy to find, some take forever to find. For all those loot lovers out there, you will love this game because of all the loot and what it takes to get it. To go into a little more depth of exploration is the moving system, to turn you can't just turn all the way around, to do that, you would have to turn sideways and look sideways again since you look always in a 90 degree angle.

To conclude, I would love to say Legend of Grimrock is a great modern day game and I would recommend it to anyone.

reviewText: Legitimately the best game I've ever played. Great puzzles, great combat mechanics, great story and (most of all) IMMERSION. It's saddening so many games lack this. You actually feel like you're trapped inside the dungeon; you actually feel scared when you know there's a stronger enemy ahead, instead of simply being more careful; you actually feel that if you take damage you're screwed, unlike some games *ahem* CoD *ahem*. Honestly, the only not so great thing that I can think about this game is that *sometimes* you move 2 squares instead of 1 because you tapped w twice by accident, which may cause you to fall into a pit. If you like RPGs, dungeon crawlers OR puzzle games, GET THIS. It's worth every cent and every minute you spend on it.

reviewText: A stirling effort from Almost Human Games here in their (in my view) near, if not flawless re-visitation of a classic genre; it pays well - earned homage to the pioneers of the genre - Eye of the Beholder, etc - as without their contributions to the multifarious world of gaming, we would never have seen such a remarkable title, namely the Legend of Grimrock, nominally reflecting its plot seamlessly.\n\nIn time, with further refinements, if even necessary, heeding the game industry's inexorable technological progression & evolution (possibly in the form of a sequel, alluded to by the game's dev's on the LoG website), I could easily expect their respectively held positions in gaming legend to invert, seeing LoG as one of the superlative titles of our generation, as its, in terms of genre, preceding titles were to theirs.

reviewText: For years I've been wanting to play a modernized old school first person dungeon crawl/RPGs. I tried going back and playing older ones like might and magic games but they just don't cut it over time. All I can say is Legend of Grimrock is EXACTLY what I've been waiting for. It takes all the fun, excitement, and strategy out of those old games and brings it to the current level of gameplay. It removes all the buggyness of older games, it replaces the confusingly blurred graphics where it's easy to miss an important item with beautiful design, poor puzzles with strategic challenges, choppy fighting with challenging battles, etc. I LOVED this game, I had so much fun playing it, and with the added function of a popular mod community and a dungeon editor it is really a top tier experience. If you like RPGs, or dungeon crawls, or have been craving what I have then look no further: this game is TONS of fun.

reviewText:
A much longer game than expected.  Somehow I assumed it would be shorter since it has downloadable levels through Steamworks.

I enjoyed playing it since it is a throw back to the original days of PC gaming and RPG's.  Took me about 17 hours to complete with breaks/getting lost.  I tried not to use any walkthroughs but I had to at the last area only to go... duh....

The combat is slow pace to start but by floor 8 out of 13, you need to start being fast and moving around monsters or you'll die.  You can create your own team/race/class set up with four chars and create your own playstyle.  I had two tanks (sword/mace) and two mages (fire/earth).

The downside is I started to get bored around floor 9, but decided to rush to the end and beat it.  Luckily floors 11-13 are somewhat qucik.  Cool if you dig old PC gamestyle, but most will likely be turned off by a game like this.

reviewText: This right here.  Wizardry, Megami Tensei.  This is the future here.  Puzzles, exploration, a minimalist story, a creator's kit.  It's all good stuff.\n\nThe Legend of Grimrock is a first person, real time dungeon RPG wherein you control a group of up to four prisoners dropped on the top of a dungeon mountain, given a trial by Tomb of Horrors.  You need to navigate through puzzles, traps and nopeworthy monsters, keeping in mind your placement and that of your enemies, the combinations needed for spells, the spaces in your inventory and much more to manage combat well.  It can be fast paced at times, and healing options are scarce between battles.  The environment and graphics are splendid, and while a bit short, it's cheap and offers a number of community made dungeons.  I dig it.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock is one of a very small litter of games that attempts to create a classic dungeon crawler similar to those of the old days such as Dungeon Master and succeeds in not only emulating that style, but updating it enough to make it a refreshing experience for modern gamers, as well as a familiar one.

A feature I found to be charming (as well as terrifying) was the option to play the game on a Classic difficulty that forces you to draw your own maps out on grid paper, much like old pen-and-paper tabletop games. I myself haven't been brave enough to give this playthrough a try yet, but I still find it to be a wonderful option for true gluttons of punishment.

As deeply rewarding as it is challenging, with lots of replay value, and great Steam Workshop options to keep the game new for even the most frequent players, LoG is a for sure winner. I'll be eagerly awaiting the release of the second game, ready to brave the dangers between the dungeon walls once more.

reviewText:
great trip down memory lane.

Plusses:
-15+ hours gameplay
-great puzzles
-good challenge even on easy
-13 levels of dungeons (most of them take 1½-2 hours to complete)
-nicely paced
-loads of secret areas

minusses:
-controles can be confusing in the heat of battle, and sometimes you go one square more than you wanted, resulting in falling in a pit or cornering yourself.
-could have been a few more spells per mage type (only 4)
-could have been a few more weapons and armor pieces
-some puzzles can be VERY difficult/frustrating to complete, due to controles

conclussion:
a must buy for those fan of dungeon crawling games. even those who have no experience with it (such as me) its a must buy. its one of those games you dont think much of when you see it. but youll be plenty satisfied when you play it.
movement is fluent, combat is fluent. puzzles are nicely challenging, ranging from super easy to mindbuggling difficult.
all in all 13.99 euro for this is well worth it

reviewText:
Grimrock... I have never had a game ever before take me back so very far into my gaming past. Way back, there was a game called Dungeon Master. It was the first adventure game I played, and this game replicates it perfectly in terms of gameplay. The game engine, the puzzles, everything about it just screams that this is one game that will take up a lot of your time.

The gameplay itself is solid. You move on a grid, everything happens in real time, you have to eat, you sleep to regain health and mana, your torches burn out. So much management that most modern adventure games seem to miss, that add to the experience. The puzzles are well thought out, take effort to solve and are satisfying to get past. Combat is fast paced, requiring thought as well as a fast clicking finger.

This is one game that remains true to the classic, old adventure games of gaming yore. Whether you remember that time or not, this is one experience not to be missed.

reviewText: $15 or less gets you a remarkably well-designed retro-style dungeon crawler, complete with a four player party (of Humans, Minotaurs, Lizardmen and Insectoids), a wide range of devious traps and puzzles (which you really don't see in RPGs anymore), and some very challenging fights.\n\nIt has all of the features of a classic first-person RPG - tile-based movement, dying of starvation, reading bits of the story off scrolls, and the like - mixed with the accessibility and graphics of a modern, big-ish budget RPG...so it's both nostaglic and a refreshing change of pace for the genre? Eh, I'm crapping on, just buy it.

reviewText:
Not since Portal have I played a puzzle game that made me feel both stupid and empowered when I figured out the answer was right in front of my face. Legend of Grimrock combines an old-school dungeon crawler mixed with puzzles and RPG elements.

Synopsis: You control a group of 4 prisoners trying to escape Grimrock by solving puzzles and fighting monsters. Puzzles can be as simple as a hidden button on a wall or as complex that things may take time and patience to solve.
Gameplay: The best way I can describe this game is if you mixed D&D and Myst, with tons of aggravation. The Legend of Grimrock isn’t as one dimensional as the art style and movement may lead you to believe. Many of the puzzles will leave you scratching your head and swearing there isn’t a solution. The other aspect of the game which I believe could use some work is the battle system. As intricate as the puzzles can be, the system to fight monsters throughout gets repetitive and leaves a lot to be desired. It’s a mix between real time and turn based, with a focus on the formation of your team. If your characters use all short range abilities, you have to swap one of the two, for the one you want to attack. Many monsters can be defeated without much strategy and sometimes become a hindrance to trying to solve a puzzle. There are four classes you can choose from as you customize your perfect party, but very little direction or tutorial on how to use each class. I found myself having to look up a guide on how to use a mage to even understand what magic could be used. I have logged thirty-eight hours on this title (some of it was afk during a multiplayer game), but at less than $5, 20 hours of engrossing gameplay and a strong community following, this game is more than worth it.

Positive:
+Challenging puzzles are intricate enough to make you feel clever
+Game can be saved at any point.
+Large community following where content can be downloaded.

Negative
-Battle system can get repetitive.
-Not all classes are created equal.

Art Style/Graphics:  Think old school, first person, dungeon crawler. This game is a great blend of classic nostalgia with a jolt of current 3d graphics. Much of the game in spent in the darkness with two to three walls around you, but this doesn’t mean the creators were lazy. Attention is paid to simple cracks in the wall, to how the light bounces off each wall. To speak more about the lighting; this plays a huge role on the tone of the gameplay. The torches on the walls (or the ones you drop on the ground) limit vision to what can be around the next turn, which makes you feel like you are actually there.

Positive:
+Lighting is engaging.
+Can be played on lower-end computers.
+Can be played in Windowed Mode

Negative:
-Characters and enemies could be upgraded.

Soundtrack/Sound effects: This was one of the biggest negatives to the game for me. For the 20 hours I played, much of the time was spent trying to solve puzzles. To solve puzzles you have to explore the dungeon, often falling to lower parts. Hearing my characters yell as they were falling, over and over, got very annoying. This is only increased by the often reused sounds of the characters attacking and grunting in every fight they encounter. On a positive note, the minor sounds of metal doors closing, walls moving, or crackling of the fire, add a realistic aspect and can be heard in surround sound.

Positive:
+Simple sounds of environment

Negative:
-Repetitive

Cost: I personally bought this game in a Humble Bundle (only paying $5), but that being said, I would wait for this game to go on sale. $14 (full price) is a bit too much for the amount of gameplay in the standalone. At 75% off ($3.75) a case can be made. This does not include the amount of community related additions on the workshop; which is extensive
Positive:

+HUGE community created content

Negative:
-Full price not worth standalone

reviewText:
If you're into this type of a game I'm sure you will like it but there are two things you should know about this game that I didn't when I got it:

It is not turn based. You move and attack in real-time.

The dungeons are static and are not randomly generated. The enemies are also not randomized in any way. This kills replayability for me.

The graphics are great and the gameplay is strategic enough to keep interest up, but honestly speaking it's not really my type of game. I still recommend you buy it if you find the gameplay interesting!

reviewText: Legitimately the best game I've ever played. Great puzzles, great combat mechanics, great story and (most of all) IMMERSION. It's saddening so many games lack this. You actually feel like you're trapped inside the dungeon; you actually feel scared when you know there's a stronger enemy ahead, instead of simply being more careful; you actually feel that if you take damage you're screwed, unlike some games *ahem* CoD *ahem*. Honestly, the only not so great thing that I can think about this game is that *sometimes* you move 2 squares instead of 1 because you tapped w twice by accident, which may cause you to fall into a pit. If you like RPGs, dungeon crawlers OR puzzle games, GET THIS. It's worth every cent and every minute you spend on it.

reviewText:
Giving a simple thumbs-up or thumbs-down to Legend of Grimrock seems to me to miss the point of the game; it was consciously designed for a very specific audience, and your enjoyment will depend upon your belonging to said audience.

I'd describe Grimrock as a puzzle game with an RPG overlay. You're dumped on top of a mountain and have to fight and puzzle your way through a series of dungeon levels in order to get to the exit at the bottom. There's an opening graphic about being condemned to the maze and offered a slim chance at survival as punishment for unspecified crimes, like eating puppies or promoting Justin Bieber's music or somesuch. Unimportant; it's a reason for your four-person party to wind up stuck in a dungeon. Players of the Recent Might and Magic X: Legacy will find it has less involved, less tactically sophisticated combat but much tougher puzzles (it pains me to admit that I got stumped fairly early on); you look for a hidden switch that opens a door somewhere on the other end of the level that leads to a dead end with another switch disguised as a torch sconce that when pulled opens the gate you saw three turns back which leads to a scrap of paper with a password on it for that magical barrier you couldn't get past before...

I've given Legend of Grimrock a thumbs-up because it seems to do what it set out to do: it provides a series of tougher and tougher dungeon puzzles for the player to obsess over, with some simple combat to leaven it. The game's a bit like extra-dark chocolate in that respect: people who already find it to their taste will love it, while people who don't will find it has a bitter, gritty flavour that sort of reminds them of something they like.

reviewText: Grimrock is a really fun game that harkens back to the Bard's Tale type games that I used to play on the C64 back in High School.  Great dungeon crawler with a good story and RPG elements.  Fun and interesting levels to explore that are fortunately not so complicated that you'd need graph paper for mapping.  The only thing I didn't like was that to defeat enemies past a certain point you often have to sort of strafe and attack to kill them - I don't mind fighting like that in a more action game, but for a game like this, that mechanic felt a little out of place.  Still, a great game for an old school type dungeon crawler RPG.  Highly recommended.

reviewText:
A throwback game to old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs, Legend of Grimrock easily succeeds at that, with a feature that, I feel, should’ve been in all those old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear. It plays like one, it has absolutely no music, but rather, ambient sounds like none of them, it has hard fighting monsters like one, and in this review, that’s only scratching the surface. Let’s dig a bit deeper, and see what this game really offers.

Gameplay: As mentioned earlier, Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of the late 80s to the early 90s (or at least, I think that’s when these games were hot) and it succeeds at what it set out to do, too. It’s setting is that of Mount Grimrock, a large dungeon inside a mountain, and every bit of it is in first-person. The combat is somewhat fast-paced, but not so fast that you have to be faster than greased lightning to be able to get through fights. Their are helpful hints, if a bit obscure in places, that tell you how to proceed, and plenty of puzzles and traps to slog your way through.

Story: The story in Legend of Grimrock feels a lot more fleshed-out than those games from which it takes its inspiration, such as the Dungeon Master games. Basically, though, the whole story amounts to this: you and your party members are prisoners convicted of an unknown crime, and you have been promised your freedom if you can escape from the dungeons of Mount Grimrock. Problems is, is that no one has ever managed to escape from Mount Grimrock, or at least, those who’ve been pardoned in this manner never have. It’s cliché, yes, but it works as a good driving force, because you’ll want to see what the King or whoever it is that sentenced your party to be pardoned in this way since you’ll inevitably be the first ones to ever escape this fate, right? But it actually goes deeper than that, because your party has dreams telling them of an original prisoner in the dungeon who knows the way out. I won’t say anymore on the story, because then I’d have to spoil it for you, and that wouldn’t be any fun, now would it?

Music: As I said earlier, this game only has one particular song, and it only plays on the title screen. It’s pretty good, too!

Graphics: The graphics look like about what you’d be expecting from a Dungeon Crawler that takes its inspiration from Dungeon Master, but with a modern day take on them. They look like graphics that you’d see in a modern day game.

Now, that’s everything that’s in the game itself, but the game’s true strength really shines with the built-in Dungeon Editor. That’s right! Now you can make the Dungeon Master dungeons of your dreams with a bit more interactivity, thanks to Lua scripting and the Drag-and-Drop editing power of the Dungeon Editor for Legend of Grimrock.

Overall, an amazing successor to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear, Legend of Grimrock is an obvious success, and it’s one in which I hope you can escape the shackles that will undoubtedly hold you to it and keep you coming back for more!

reviewText:
Nostalgia FTW.  This will bring back fond memories of the dungeon crawlers of yore.  They even have a mode where there is no automap so you can sharpen your pencils and get out the graph paper (with an achievement for completing the game this way, naturally).   The setup is basic - you create 4 characters, chosing between classes (Fighter, Rogue, Mage) and races (human, minotaur, insectoid, and lizardmen).  You have the basic stats such as strength, dexterity, willpower, and vitality, and are given a pool of points to assign them at the beginning as well as selecting a couple of traits to your character (Athletic, agile, strong mind, etc).  Your initial stats will only be increased by leveling up skills - and they display the complete tree and bonuses earned with each level so you can plan accordingly.

For the base game, there is a good mix of combat and puzzles to solve, though items and maps are static - no random loot here.  However, the game comes with a dungeon editor and there is a healthy selection in the Steam Workshop to give you plenty of replayability.

I've beaten the game twice - the second time was a bit of achievement farming as well as trying different character builds.  The sound is adequate - no award winning voicework apart from some grunts, there are just a couple of cutscenes, all of which can be clicked through very quickly, and the bones of the story are pretty bare.  You're all convicts that have been awarded a pardon - which you receive once you are cast into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock.  From there, you are working your way down, following the path of some other criminal who left notes behind that provide a little bit of background, clues to puzzles, and so on. This is NOT turn-based - you click each character's action and wait for the cooldowns to expire before that character can act again. As such, you can maneuver around in combat, dodging, moving out of range, or even circling around behind the enemy for a backstabbing attack (if your rogue has that skill).

I recommend the game for fans of the old RPG crawlers.

reviewText:
You know, I grew up on dungeon crawler games and D&D. This really harkens back to those days. Loads of nostalgia, but definitely with modern creativity and a beautiful look and feel. The editor is a great touch to allow for some replayability.

It definitely has a wizardry feel, but utilizes their own leveling, and skill system, which to me is quite refreshing, albeit more simplified.

I definitely strongly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys D&D, RPG's, and dungeon crawling games. I hope to see a lot more from the creators of this game.

reviewText:
9/10
So i bought this game a while ago, but didn't really start logging many hours into it until recently.
This game is great--if you're a fan of oldschool dungeon crawler games, I highly suggest you look into the Legend of Grimrock series.
A few notes:
-This game is fairly easy to add content to, such as extra player portraits
-Does not lag, seems to run pretty well on most machines
-You can choose to fill in the map as you go, classic style
-Doesn't have turn based gameplay, but rather each character has a cooldown on their weapons
-Spell system is intrigueing and somewhat reminiscent of magicka
-Straightforward gameplay
-Challenging without being unnecessarily difficult
-Graphics are okay, not top of the class but still decent

reviewText:
Yes, I know, it's a whiny statement, but let me kind of explain why I feel this way and perhaps it'll make more sense.

I get the dungeon crawl concept. I've played them before, and roguelikes. Against all expectations, I beat the hardest of hardcore modes on Dungeons of Dredmor, I went through a couple playthroughs of Dark Souls, all that stuff. When I lose in those games, I feel it's because I did something to mess up, missed a move or made a wrong decision.

With this game, there is no wrong decision to make, because no matter what you decide, you get thrown up against a difficulty spike that you can't possibly be ready for until you die at least once to it. If it isn't the obtuse puzzles that only make sense about half the time, it's the enemies that pop out of nowhere, can take forty times as many hits as any of your characters, and deal out damage that can kill you in seconds in a straight fight.

I know a lot of people may disagree with this, and they certainly have a right to. But to me, this game isn't a challenge, or a dungeon crawl. It's just mashing my face against random walls in the hopes of finding a hidden switch, and getting killed a dozen times by the same overpowered monster group until I find the hidden cheese tactic that somehow lets me go down another floor.

reviewText: As the game begins, you are released into a grimdark dungeon crawler that looks to be fantastic. This is veneer. reviewText:
To make it short and sweet, this game can't decide what it wants to be. The base systems it sets up are sound, their levelling and RPG and class/team building mechanics are all solid and interesting.

Then the combat throws all that out the window and makes you essentially try and play an FPS on a grid by circle strafing and dodging and such. There is little sense of type weaknesses, formation shuffling, tactical considerations, or any other interesting RPG type mechanics; just running around enemies and tapping the attack buttons until they die.

This gets progressively worse throughout the game, with more and more bullet sponge" enemies
date: until what might be the worst final boss fight I've had the displeasure to experience in a long time
hoursPlayed: mechanics and comprehensibility.\n\nMaybe try that new Might and Magic game if you want an actual dungeon crawler

reviewText:
I had few problem with this game. First I thought it was turned based like the classic games of this genre I played in the past. The game is in real time.  Not a huge problem so lets go on.  All the levels look the same. The game looks boring.  There seems to be only one tile set.  The bigget problem is the controls. The game moves like a tank.  If you hold down a movement key you can over shoot the spot you wanted to stop at. This because a big problem when dealing with timed puzzles and traps.

The one thing that made me drop the game is that timing is directly related to screen resolution and graphic card power.  There were traps and puzzles that were impossible to get through without lowering my resolution to reduce the speed of the trap.   Now this is mainly a hardware issue for people that good graphic cards.   However, I feel the game was  poorly designed  for the traps they had.

The limited classes and portraits just added to my let down but didn't effect the game much.  For me this is a insult to the old school dungeon crawlers I played in the past.

reviewText:
I went into this game thinking it was a dungeon crawling RPG. It walks like one, quacks like one, and a whole lot of people seem to think it is one.

This, however, is a Tomb Raider game. From the fixed item locations, to the limited use/high power dynamic of bombs, to mashing attack while jumping around like an idiot, to timed switch flipping, to the literal treasure hunting, to the inexplicable end boss, this is through-and-through a classic Tomb Raider game.

Is it a good Tomb Raider game though? Eh, kinda. Better than Tomb Raider 3. Like Tomb Raider the game would be much improved by more complex movement options, but it still does most of what's possible in the limited vocabulary it offers. I was disappointed, but I did not feel my time was wasted.

Note for laptop owners: thanks to a bug in the game's trackpad recognition several timed puzzles will be much harder than they need to be. They're still possible, but will require frame perfect accuracy.

reviewText:
This is an absolutely beautiful game. But that's the only good thing I can say.

I *really* wanted to like this game. I adore roguelikes and I used to play games just like this in DOS. However, combat nothing but tediously waiting for cooldowns to finish so that I can click for the next attack. Enemies have way too much health, so fights are too long (hint: more enemies with lower health makes for better games). Making the game real time rather than turn based was a major mistake, because it turns everything into a reflex clickfest. This is exactly why I didn't like Lands of Lore from way back, but at least that game had a story and voice acting and such.

reviewText:
Growing up I would often play games on my fathers DOS only PC (I know right, a PC without Windows/Mac, crazy huh?). One of the games that I would often play was Eye of the Beholder. I would never make it past the second dungeon but that was ok with me, I just enjoyed making my party and exploring the awesome dungeons.

As I got older I would ocassionally look EotB up and give it a try. And on one such occasion I came across this gem of a game. At the time, this game was in development. But I wanted it so bad I could taste it. When the game was finally released I waited up all night for them to E-Mail me my download link. I did nothing but play this game for the next two days.

All I can do is give my heavy reccomendation that everyone play this game. It is a total throwback to old school dungeon crawling RPG's. The game plays so flawlessly and true to the original style that I sometimes forget that it is now 2014, and go back in time to my childhood.

Serioulsy, buy this game.

reviewText:
I'm going to offer a dissenting opinion on this one, because it seems all the other grognards can't seem to take off their rose-tinted glasses and put on their real prescription lenses. Furthermore, this review is going to be different from most of the others, in that I'm going to focus on the controls. Read on and you'll see why.

Essentially, this is the most awkward-controlling dungeon crawl I've ever played. It shouldn't be actively difficult to get my characters to do what I want. A lot of people defending the control scheme will say that this is how the old games played. Which old games, exactly, had controls like this? I played the old Wizardry. I played the old Might and Magic. I played the old Ultima. Those are the first in the CRPG genre, and they all managed to be much easier to handle than this. FFS, the old Wizardry games made you type out the spell names! No, scrambling to manage a UI during real-time combat doesn't simulate the rush of combat--it just serves to frustrate me. Having to click on a small area of the screen with speed and accuracy isn't nostalgic, since all the firsts of the genre didn't have mouse input. It's scientifically-proven bad design. Yes, there's real science behind it: it's called Fits's Law. Maybe if you're a twitch gamer you'll like this, but I just found it frustrating and tiresome.

I grew up playing the firsts of the genre, and Grimrock doesn't resemble them at all--or if it does, I wasn't able to get to a point where I could appreciate it, because the controls are so bloody difficult. This game was an exercise in awkwardness and frustration that I haven't felt while gaming in a very long time. Don't confuse bad game design with challenge: the two are distinctly different.

reviewText:
I've noticed a trend in my reviews: I tend to only review games that I have a negative opinion of.

NOT ANY MORE!

I thought this game was very good. Not amazing, or fantastic, but very good. The puzzles can be diabolical, and the boss fight at the end can be a frustrating test of patience, but overall, Almost Human did a great job with it.

Combat is almost always fast-paced and hectic (trying to click on the right runes for a mage while trying to dodge attacks from multiple enemies is a blast), the graphics are rather impressive, the puzzles are satisfying (for the most part), and the variety of enemies is very welcome indeed.

Many games of this genre can get boring, as they are truly turn-based, and you can take your time, but not with this game. Your characters have a food (hunger) bar that continually shrinks, even when standing still. Add to that the fact that food is not by any means a common find in the dungeons, and you have a real motivation to always keep moving.

There were a few places where you could grind for food, and I wish I hadn't discovered that fact, as it took away quite a bit of the urgency of the situation. If/when you play through, I would strongly suggest you not take advantage of any grinding opportunities you come across (they won't be too easy to find anyway), as the game is fair about food, and will give you as much as you need. With my grind, by the end of the game, all my characters were slightly overburdened with food that I refused to throw away.

Character designing is a lot of fun, and trying different combos of teams adds quite a bit of replay value, although certain teams work a lot better together than others.

Puzzle solutions are always sensical, although some of them are rather esoteric. Clues on pieces of paper and random items you find are almost always relevant to puzzles, so keep your wits about you.

Overall, this game is an example of just about everything done just about perfectly. It's not an easy game, but it's not punishingly difficult either. It never asked for more than I could give, but it was always close.

Plus, indie team. Always awesome.

Legend of Grimrock misleads the buyers to think it would be an oldschool dungeoncrawler. When in reality its a puzzlecrawler!

Puzzle are chained after each other, so you get the feeling after some hours of playing, that if you manage to solve a puzzle, the reward is a puzzle, who would have guessed...

It gets really boring, when you simply wanna crawl through a dungeon, but have to solve one thing after the other. Puzzles in general would be fine, but they're mostly just walking the wrong way until you find the right one. Rarely there are real puzzles to solve.

There are some good things I can't deny, the game looks great and would be a real blast if it would be a real dungeoncrawler. A good thing is you can play the playermade dungeons.

The original game though just gives me the feeling it was designed this way, to mislead the player into thinking the game had decent length. (really short)

I bought the game at full prize, because of the overhyped reviews people give and the misleading promoting the makers give on their side, I quote directly from their website:  The ultimate dungeon crawling RPG"

reviewText:
The feel and presentation are superb but the actual game mechanics themselves leave much to be desired. By that I mean theres little depth to the RPG elements or they simply do not properly work. Playing a rogue for example, putting points into Missile weapons gains you Dex points, which affect your ability to hit in Melee, but not from a distance. Ranged attacks always hit something in front of you. Dex does not increase your damage with ranged atacks so by extension if you focus on using a bow for one of your characters, you'll build a stat that is nearly useless to them. This is by definition bad game design.

Furthermore, I admire loot being hard to comeby, but not supporting all builds from the outset is dumb. If you're doing the above and making one of your characters an archer, then I hope to god you find the secret bow on level 3 or else you've been literally screwed. This is a game that should promote and reward exploration with better and special equipment but instead twists your arm into looking up secrets online to get the most basic of equipment.

Overall, if you love the concept of this game then buy the sequel or stick to user made dungeons.

reviewText: Lots of mixed feelings about Grimrock.  I had fun while playing it for sure, but the visuals are reptetitive, the interface is weird, and the controls are awful—trying to be cute and nostalgic by only allowing you to turn 90 degrees at a time.  But the worst part is that a game so full of secret buttons and levers and rooms requires you to find most of them.  This is a HARD game, and I can't imagine being able to complete it without finding a decent chunk of all of the tiny little hidden buttons in the walls, which means carefully inspecting every single surface of the dungeon, often with some sort of time requirement, or alt-tabbing to a guide (this one's awesome by the way: http://guides.gamepressure.com/legendofgrimrock/ ).  And that was fun and nostalgic for a while, but was incredibly tedious by the end.  (And even the Might and Magic games of more than 20 years ago didn't make me hunt for the pixel to click on.)

reviewText:
The most important thing to understand about this game is that it absolutely is not ... not ... an old-school RPG.  If you are looking for an old-school RPG this is not what you're looking for.  I would go so far as to say the suggestion that it is an old-school RPG is borderline false advertising.

This is a puzzle game wrapped in the trappings of an old-school RPG, and played in real time rather than turn-based.  Combat is a dance puzzle with button mashing.  There are no tactics.  Magic is encumbered with rune selection, which must be done in real time, making casters a liability.  Rogues are just another combatant, there is no thieving.

There is no story to speak of.  When you're not solving puzzles, you are seeking hidden buttons and pattern differences in wall tiles.

Is it fun?  Yes, it's not bad as far as puzzle games go, nor is it anything special.  Yet, it's nothing but a puzzle game and that wasn't what I wanted.  I usually avoid Indie games, and now I will never buy an Indie game again.  I feel like I was conned, and robbed, and that this game has been intentionally marketed to fool old-school gamers for profit.
voteText: 11 of 27 people (41%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I wanted to like this one. Really, I did. I'm all about old school RPGs, it comes with the Jim Sterling seal of approval, and I enjoy games that let me throw my own content in a bit, like with the portriats...

That said, I couldn't do it.

The combat is tiresome, tedious, and unrewarding. The interface is clunky and amatuerish. The bestiary is lifeless, the puzzels are unfulfilling, and worst of all, there's no dialog for all intents and purposes. This is as souless of a dungeon crawler as I've ever seen, devoid of wit, story, motivation, and wholly undeserving of the level of hype it's gotten.

I can put up with it's old timey grid gimmick - maybe even enjoy the novelty some. But that's all that it brings to the table, and it isn't anywhere near enough. The interface needs a complete overhaul, the combat needs a lot of work, and for the love of Skyrim put some plot and dialog in! A straight up dungeon crawl can work, but you really need to frame it better - give me more of a world, give me context and a story. Give me details and motivation and reward me with more than a set of stairs and a big spoonful of the exact same thing I just did.

I gave it a chance, and it isn't for me.

reviewText:
Concept: a band of four prisoners is taken to the dungeon of Grimrock for their crimes, where none thus far have ever escaped.

Gameplay: despite its appearance, it is NOT turn-based. It's realtime, although most enemies' movements have LONG delays. You navigate on a strict grid and cannot cut diagonals. The combat consists of clicking weapons and hoping for special attacks, or clicking magic and casting your own damn spell. Not that the rune system really helps you.

Graphics: look closely and you'll notice that the texture on the face of every wall is exactly the same. The graphics, even aside from the walls, are pretty lazy, although the monsters are fine. However, the headbobbing of moving around is a wonderful way to get sick.

Audio: no music. Just generic, boring ambience and a single audio effect for each monster that you get to hear 20 times a minute.

Difficulty: dungeon crawler. It has difficulty settings, although I have only played one difficulty thus far, so I've no idea what the difficulty affects.

Synopsis: hardly worth $15(but I got it cheaper) unless you're really into dungeon crawlers.

reviewText:
As an original fan of the Dungeon Master Series Legend of Grimrock held quite a bit of appeal for me. The game almost perfectly emulates  the gameplay of the classic series while bringing the visuals nicely up to date.

GAMEPLAY
Similar to another Classic Series (Elder Scrolls), LoG casts you in the role of Prisoners being exiled for unknown reasons into the catacombs of Mount Grimrock. The focus of the gameplay is on combat and puzzle solving, the latter of which can sometimes be maddeningly frustrating, but very satisfying when you finally work it through.

While you have complete freedom to go anywhere you want within the dungeon movement is grid based and fixed to the cardinal directions, up, down, left, right, and turning.  Some people (mostly new school gamers) find this limitation madden and arbitrary, but it plays an important role in gameplay and tactics.


STORY
The story is there, but is very, very light. There are lots of little bits and pieces of info scatterd throughout (esp the story of former dungeon Denzien Toorum). You're ultimately left with more questions than answers, but you don't walk away feeling unsatisfied, and that's what the expanded Story in Grimrock 2 is for as well.

In general if you are fan of or think you will enjoy the old grid based style then you'll like this game. But if you're not, pass

reviewText:
This game is simply not for me.  Why you ask?  Because I seem to solve puzzles differently than how the game developer intended in Legend of Grimrock.  The game itself is fairly good for a dungeon crawler, with decent graphics, simple gameplay, and not too demanding hardware specifications.  The game relies on solving a series of puzzles and finding things to advance to the next level.  The game is linear, and if you don't solve the problem in the exact manner intended by the game developer, you WILL BE STUCK, like I've been.

The first time I time I played, I used a custom party of 1 fighter, 1 rogue, 2 mages, and I found the mages to be useless cheerleaders due to a lack of access to spells.  No problem.  Start a new game.  Second round of 2 fighters, 1 rogue, 1 mage seemed to be a better fit for the challenges awaiting me on level one.  However, there was a portion of the dungeon with 1 pit and 2 pressure plates, with snails waiting behind the gate.  I got past the pit with no trouble, and the gate lifted.  However, during the encounter I moved off the plate, and the gate slammed shut, with no way to lift.  From my previous playthrough with my abandoned party, I knew that this area was important in order to advance to the next stage.  With no way to lift the gate, I was stuck.  Thus, I needed to restart the level.

Moving on to level 2, I almost cleared out the entire dungeon, if I could only find the two keys for the keyholes to the left and right out of gate, with a portal beckoning me to enter.  Unfortunately, I got stuck again.  Why? Because at the portion of the dungeon with two hidden rooms, I did not realize there was a second hidden room, with a key located there. I found 1 key in the room past the teleport trap, and used it.  When I retraced my step, I couldn't get the door to the second hidden room to open no matter how many times I pressed the hidden switch.  It appears that by using the key, I broke the script.  So now I've put five hours into the game, and I'm looking at the prospect of a third restart of the game.  Not worth it. :(

reviewText: Legend of Grimrock is a dungeon crawling role playing game with an oldschool heart but a modern execution. A group of prisoners are sentenced to certain death by exiling them to the secluded Mount Grimrock for vile crimes they may or may not have committed. Unbeknownst to their captors, the mountain is riddled with ancient tunnels, dungeons and tombs built by crumbled civilizations long perished now. If they ever wish to see daylight again and reclaim their freedom the ragtag group of prisoners must form a team and descend through the mountain, level by level.\n\nThe game brings back the oldschool challenge with highly tactical real-time combat and grid-based movement, devious hidden switches and secrets as well as deadly traps and horrible monsters. Legend of Grimrock puts an emphasis on puzzles and exploration and the wits and perception of the player are more important tools than even the sharpest of swords could be. And if you are a hardened dungeon crawling veteran and you crave an extra challenge, you can arm yourself with a stack of grid paper and turn on the Oldschool Mode which disables the luxury of the automap! Are you ready to venture forth and unravel the mysteries of Mount Grimrock?

reviewText: Grimrock is beautifully crafed and oozes with atmosphere and old-school charm. Unfortunately it sets no higher goals for itself; it merely puts a spit shine on the past, without attempting to update or modernize any of the rickety old systems that make up its core gameplay. It makes no effort to evolve, and that, ultimately, is why the game fails; it is content with mediocrity in every area that matters, while being exceptional in those that do not. It's entertaining and nostalgic, but I can't recommend it on any other terms.

reviewText: I bought this really cheap. Its an old school dungeon crawler with a 3D perspective. Kind of like you're stuck in an Elder Scrolls dungeon that is randomly generated. The easy is very easy, each area is blocked by a door and you need to get something that opens the door. Get a torch, pull a lever, find a key. Simple stuff. Everything is built in a grid, so you walk one square at a time. Oh and you can look, walk and strafe, but to turn you either need to use a key or hold left mouse button and drag the mouse to the side. This game has a slow pace that not everyone will like. At its best it feels like a modern Shadowgate... at its worst its clunky with boring combat where you click and see a poor animation. I have a tough time justifying more than $5 for this.

reviewText:
Ugh, what a load of GARBAGE... my God... this looked like it had so much promise but it's just a disaster of a game.

I thought the combat was going to be a bit better but really this game is just walking through boring square shaped hallways. I hate the idea that the game runs on rails to a degree and I don't have a free roam 360 perspective... it makes the game as a whole insanely tedious, clunky and boring.

There aren't any quick keys for potions or abilities either. The mage is practically worthless in a fight because of how obnoxious it is to cast spells. The characters in the back are annoying to use in battle as well and demand a long range weapon which sometimes leaves them gimped. It's inanely hard to switch characters and weapons in the middle of a fight as well... I found myself running half way back through a dungeon just to make some small changes... unacceptable.

The only redeeming quality this game holds is the dungeon editor... Make your own dungeons and share them with your friends because the campaign is just brutally awful. I'm also afraid the game is too long and that worries me... it's just not worth the time spent put in to it.

Puzzles also become incredibly demanding later on because you need rocks to trigger switches so if you accidenitally threw some away or left them somewhere on the ground, have fun wasting your time backtracking or throwing valuable items like torches. All in all, not recommended unless you like this sort of thing. I thought it was going to play more like Shadowgate and it doesn't... it's just crap.

Buyer beware.... also I noticed most negative reviews for this game get thumbs down, go for it, I don't really care, the people who enjoy this game are obviously blindsided by it's crappiness...

reviewText:
NO, this is -NOT- RPG.
This is a super-repeating-to-death-pixel-hunting puzzle game.
Stay away from this if you want to play an RPG.

This is not Bard's Tale, Wizardry or Might and Magic, like it claims to be.
It is just a poor pathfinding puzzle game.

Its stat/skill system and combat mechanics are so broken that it doesn't just work out as they are supposed to be.

All you do is strafing and kiting the enemies by tile, then mindlessly walking back and forth pressing stupid plates and torturing your eyes to find random switches on the ever-same-looking walls, all the way through the day and night.

And am I supposed to have fun doing that crap? HELL NO.

If I wanted an action adventure, I would play a real one like BioShock, not this boring pseudo-action game riddled with god-awful puzzles.

reviewText:
Initially I voted Not Recommended for this game. Now that I've played Legend of Grimrock through, I decided to change my vote to Recommended with some qualification. There is a great deal to love about LoG. I only wish the developers had reconsidered a couple of design decisions.

Understand that LoG is a dungeon-crawler not truly an RPG. There is no role-playing and very little story. The only RPG elements are that you can generate your own party and determine your characters stats as they level. You interact with no other characters and converse with no one, not even your own party members. Where LoG succeeds is in its retro style and feel, but with contemporary high-quality graphics. Additionally, LoG has plenty of difficult battles, many fun and intriguing puzzles, and considerable switch-hunting (be warned). LoG is not a turn-based game as you might expect for an RPG; it's real-time. Depending on your expectations and playing style, this feature can be annoying or thrilling, because monsters can attack you unexpectedly as you view your map, manage your inventory, or even as you level up. I loved this aspect of the game.

Be aware, though, that if you have only average manual dexterity, the game can at times become very frustrating as you load, reload, ad nauseum, trying to solve" running/timing puzzles that occur in the game. A couple of these puzzles can be bypassed
date: but then you will miss some of the game's most coveted items. A few are required to progress
hoursPlayed: and these can be game-stoppers. Worse
voteText: the movement system is not really geared to running/timing puzzles because you move one square at a time
helpfulPercent: and it's quite easy to overrun your mark--yet these puzzles require precise timing without any room for error. I found it irksome that I could understand a puzzle
votesHelpful: but couldn't "solve" it because my fingers weren't fast enough. This dimension of the game made little sense to me; after all
votesTotal: the game purports to be a dungeon CRAWLER
votesFunny: and this genre traditionally relies on wit
commentsCount: thought
column16: and tactics
column17: not rapid finger movements like a platform game. I finally was able to deal with the two worst of these puzzles. For one of them
column18: I found an AutoHotKey script that with minor adjustments did the work for me; for the second
column19: inspired by the script just mentioned
column20: I developed my own AutoHotKey script. That was more challenging and satisfying than endlessly retrying a puzzle my fingers just wouldn't do.\n\nIn another odd design choice
column21: the developers required some commonplace items to solve a puzzle essential to progress in the game
column22: but then didn't include the items on that level. These were the kind of items players might have easily ditched as useless levels earlier. Being compelled to trudge back several levels to search for discarded items is not fun. Fortunately
column23: you can use the LoG console to generate the items if you don't want to bother backtracking levels.\n\nStill
column24: once you get beyond these issues
column25: Legend of Grimrock is an enthralling game. If you're new to dungeon crawlers
column26: don't expect something with the strong character interaction
column30: Dragon Age. That's not what Legend of Grimrock is about. But if the idea appeals to you of a dungeon-crawler/puzzler with heaps of combat
column33: go for it. You'll love Legend of Grimrock."

reviewText:
A beautiful love-letter to the Dungeon Crawlers of the 1970's and 80's.
Smart.
Beautiful.
Tough, but fair.

The game is PACKED with secrets, secrets, secrets and you are constantly keeping an eye on your food meter since resting while starving does you no good. The game is well-balanced but does NOT hold your hand-- this is not for your little sister to play, even on normal difficulty.

Walking on a grid system took some getting used to, but the game is well-paced enough that by the time it hits its stride you're a master at it.

The game is going to give your the best experience during the FIRST playthrough only, though. As it is a puzzle game at heart-- the puzzles don't change. Going back through a second or third time would only be for the over-achievers that want to find all the secrets, hidden items, skulls (yes skulls), treasures and so on. I got 22/40 achievements just playing it through the first time. I only had to look up the solution to two puzzles in the entire 20hrs of gameplay, and felt halway clever the rest of the time. The game does a good job of coyly telling you what to look for, then letting you walk RIGHT past it soon after and NOT getting that cool sword that's hidden in the walls.

Be patient, Be smart, Be methodical. Grimrock IS out to get you. Food is scarce and some enemies are a bit overpowered--- again, tough but fair. You'll have a blast wandering down its tunnels. I wholly recommend it.

9/10

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This review is coming from someone who did not grow up on dungeon crawler games. A great little RPG/Dungeon crawler/puzzler.  Well worth the admission price.

Pros:
-Fantastic Atmosphere
-Figuring out Puzzles make you feel like the smartest man (or woman) alive
-Linear levels, but still manages to make exploration rewarding
-Great community support (e.g., dungeon editor).
-Challenging without feeling unfair
-Can be very rewarding

Neutral:
-Decent replayability - the dungeon loses some of it's magic on subsequent playthroughs (which is one of the strongest points of the game) but interesting party possibilities exist.
-Small number of weapon upgrades for each type
-Interesting perspective being a party of characters rather than 1 character or being an omniscient controller of the party.  Some will enjoy it, some won't.

Cons:
-Combat takes some getting used to and feels slightly archaic
-RPG elements (i.e., skill trees) are a weak point, imo.  They seem poorly thought out for the vanilla game
-Some abilities/skills/stats are blatantly superior to others (particularly on higher difficulties)
-A bit of a learning curve

reviewText: The Legend of Grimrock is fantastic. It's a throwback to the old dungeon crawls, but with a twist. While the movement is tile based, the combat is real time. What this allows the game to do is something that I haven't had an RPG do since I was a child: Instill fear. When you make a movement mistake, you're back against a wall, hacking/casting at a baddie that you know is going to kill you in 5 seconds, trying desperately to keep up the attack while managing your inventory to find potions.. it's a unique experience.\n\nIt's about 15ish hours playthrough with no replayability atm, but the level editor is coming out soon. One of my favorite games of 2012 so far.

reviewText:
What was fun:

-Interesting puzzles
-Good depth of combat and tactics
-Nice atmosphere
-Solid rpg mechanics
-Lots of custom community dungeon content

Not fun:

-Searching miles generic rock walls for tiny secret switches(seriously just clear each level then check a guide and backtrack for secrets, its not fun and not worth your time looking for them),
-Abominable inventory and combat controls (trying to swtich weapons/use potions in a fight is a nightmare),
-Walking controls are also dodgy and can make executing some puzzles frustrating

Entertaining but with plenty of frustrations.

reviewText: Amazing! Kind of like a mix between Myst and Zork with great, tense combat. Scariest game I have played in a long time. It can instill a primal fear at times. Things are coming to get you! Not spooky spirits or cursed spectres, though the game has its fair share of skeletons. But things that want to shred your flesh and smash your skull! The clench is real.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This review is coming from someone who did not grow up on dungeon crawler games. A great little RPG/Dungeon crawler/puzzler.  Well worth the admission price.

Pros:
-Fantastic Atmosphere
-Figuring out Puzzles make you feel like the smartest man (or woman) alive
-Linear levels, but still manages to make exploration rewarding
-Great community support (e.g., dungeon editor).
-Challenging without feeling unfair
-Can be very rewarding

Neutral:
-Decent replayability - the dungeon loses some of it's magic on subsequent playthroughs (which is one of the strongest points of the game) but interesting party possibilities exist.
-Small number of weapon upgrades for each type
-Interesting perspective being a party of characters rather than 1 character or being an omniscient controller of the party.  Some will enjoy it, some won't.

Cons:
-Combat takes some getting used to and feels slightly archaic
-RPG elements (i.e., skill trees) are a weak point, imo.  They seem poorly thought out for the vanilla game
-Some abilities/skills/stats are blatantly superior to others (particularly on higher difficulties)
-A bit of a learning curve
